Excellent.  Cloudy brown with a foamy off white head.  Little aroma but excellent taste.  Caramel wheat taste with hidden alcohol.  I am not much on wheats but I would definitely drink this more.

UPDATED: NOV 23, 2010 Pours murky brown with a small head. Aroma is caramel, yeast and a hint of citrus.  Mouth feel is thick with little carbonation. Flavor is sweet but not cloying. Nice roast and yeast flavors mix perfectly with the sweetness. Alcohol is nowhere to be found, which is surprising considering the abv.  Finish is all malt.  Yummy

12 oz bottle. Poured a dark brown body with barely any head. Taste was full of some sort of fruit - perhaps prunes, raisons or plums...regardless the beer was smooth and easy to drink even with the 8.7% abv.

12 oz. bottle courtesy of illini08, thanks for sharing Jeremy.  pours a hazy brown with some floaties and a short lived head.  fruity aroma with some grain.  flavor didnt quite mesh for me, a fruity, wheat bock with a strange bitter after taste.

UPDATED: MAR 31, 2008 bottle poured a deep hazy reddish brown in color with sediment galore floating in the thick body. carbonation seems to be on the light side, smell of sweet pear, spices, cherry, yeast, and some honey sweetness. taste is not as fruited as the smell leads on, a little bit of a metallic acidic  twang, a good helping of wheat flavors, some caramel sweet, and a good blend of malts to round it out. interesting beer for sure, and left unfiltered for texture leads to a beer that is unique if nothing else and very good. this is definitely several styles of brewing mixed up and put in one bottle to make for an interesting style. did not know a weizen bock existed before this one.

UPDATED: AUG 20, 2007 to be fair this is the only weizenbock iv ever had, so i dont have any to compare it to. 
The color of this unfiltered concoction deserves awards alone. The dark unfiltered light that shines through this Weizenbock is so beautiful, that it really reminds me of the moon glowing faintly on a dark lit ocean.. The flavor of this thing is just as complex as hints of grapefruit, plums, (it kind of reminds me of Holiday fruits and exotic spices) cover your taste buds and I mean this thing hits like a ton of bricks but without a ton of unnecessary bitterness, the fact that this thing finishes SO smooth without a hint of the epic 8.7% alc is mystical.

UPDATED: JUN 7, 2011 Man, this one is just very fine. A really unique beer for the style, with some sour notes and a bit of cloudy funk, almost as if a Flemish sour and a traditional Weizenbock had a fender bender. Tasty!
Cloudy amber pour with a thin head, good lacing.  Aroma of citrus and yeast.  Taste of the same with a some fruit notes. Slightly bitter finish.
one of my faverites, the next best thing to the Aventinus.  Great flavor.

Amazing! Ive never had a beer that made me reconsider my entire view of beer. This one is a worldbeater. If this beer was a naval warship this would be a battleship with 15 inch guns (if size of gun was proportional to amazing depth of taste) with at least two feet of steel armor (if armor was equal to wide array of aromatic delights) and at the helm was a brazen pirate captain (standing for spicy sweetness that clouds the alcohol...and has an eye patch). Overall a fantastic beer with the best description ever, sometimes i read it to kids around a campfire.
Citrus aroma with alcohol well hidden. taste of fruit. I think it might have been bad because of alot of yeast in the bottle. will probably try again

Aroma of sweet citrus. The flavor has a wierd acidity to it that I didnt expect in a Weizen Bock but this seems like a very pleasant beer with well hidden alcohol, some spicy malts, sweet fruits, and good carbonation. What isnt pleasant is some rather yeasty bitter tones which tell me to avoid getting a case of this.

Cloudy copper color, no head, floating sediments.  Complex aroma of molasses, fruit and berries, maybe plum or prune, some yeast. Yeast and fermented berry flavor. Rather gross prune baby food aftertaste. Full of flavor, but not desirable. 
    This was my third of the most highly rated wheat beers I tried in one sitting. I wasnt pleased with any of them. So much for what the so-called experts say. I prefer the lower rated, lesser known, wheat beers. I can brew a better beer in my kitchen.

Another good one from Victory. Very dark in color. Nice aroma of ripe fruit maybe raisins or plums? Sweet taste of spices and fruit. No hint of the alcohol until it warms a bit. Everything Victory puts out is worth a try. This is no exception.

This is a very smooth beer with little carbonation.  The aroma does have a hint of black cherries but the taste is not sour at all.  There is also a hint of spices in the taste as well.  Perhaps some nutmeg?  The alcohol content does not come to the forefront of this beer.

Bouteille de 12 oz achetée chez Oak Tree Discount (South Plainfield, NJ). Arôme: Odeur de banane et de caramel avec une pointe de céréales. Apparence: La couleur est ambrée foncée voilée avec une présence de dépôt avec une faible densité de bulle. Présence dun mince col mousseux sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de banane et dépices. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Présence de petits fruits en arrière goût. (Rating #992)

UPDATED: AUG 17, 2007 12 oz bottle. Poured a dark brown body with barely any head. Taste was full of some sort of fruit - perhaps prunes, raisons or plums...regardless the beer was smooth and easy to drink even with the 8.7% abv.

I think this is a style of beer I will have to experiment with, but I did not like Victorys Moonglow.  I cant rule out the possiblity of a bad bottle though.  The beer looked nice/amber color.  The taste is hard to describe, but not pleasant for me:  tastes of cherries, dark fruit, burnt carmel, maybe molassess and this very strange medicine/cleaner taste.  It seemed like this beer was a good idea but was somehow off the mark.

Cloudy dark amber/chestnut pour with a partially receding, then steady cream colored head. The nose is redolent with clove, banana, guava, dusty wheat, alcoholic fruit cocktail, mild caramel and is all wrapped up into a lovely and compact, but restrained aroma. Sweet biscuity malts are the predominant flavor, along with a now complete articulation of a dense profile laced with more banana and tropical fruits, wheat, caramel, sweet alcohol(like an unfiltered, milky vodka) and some lingering spice. Finishes dry and sudden, crisp and full bodied at the same time, without any lingering or distracting syrup in the flighty mouthfeel. A fantastic rendition.

I had this at an Oktoberfest event in Virginia. t was the stand out of all the the beers I sampled.  Really warmed me up on a cold and rainy day, complex flavor.  I also had this in a bottle version, which I didnt care for as much...not a session beer for me.

Bottle.  Prune, wheat and astringent bock aroma.  Hazy read-dark amber color with small head.  Prune and oyster flavor with mild astringency.  Would have liked this better with more Weizen characteristics - this primarily only has bock characteristics.

12oz bottle-pours a foamy light tan head and copper color.  Aroma is rich medium malt-sweet caramel, medium fruit-fermented cherry, wheat, nutmeg.  Taste is wheat, medium fruit-fermented cherry, medium malt-sweet caramel, wheat, nutmeg.  OK/mild carbonation.
Lots of sweet malts in the aroma.Medium copper with an off white head.Get a lot of yeast and some hints of wheat in the flavor.Medium mouthfeel with some sweet malts in the finish.
Definite wheat aroma, yeast, and some malt.  Hazy brown body sports a full palate with lots of sweet caramel malt and wheat flavors.  Some mollasses and raisins can be detected--good brew.

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2007 12 oz Bottle-pours an orange copper color w/no head. Somewhat fruity aroma. Sweet flavor of roasted nuts, banana, yeast, & cloves. Does have a dark wheat flavor. Tangy, maybe w/some lime. Long finish-you dont really taste the alcohol. 

Rerate-On Tap-10/14/07-Much fresher flavor on tap. Had a much better dark fruit, plum, banana, spice, cane sugar, malt presence to it. Very Enjoyable.

12 oz bottle.  Milky brown with a thin tan head that fades to none.  Strong banana, lime and caramel.  Very tangy banana to start.  Quite saturated flavorwise with a medium body.  Gets oily and a little hot.  Wheat paste finish with lingering green olives and bitter cloves.
12 oz. bottle via trade with shadey - Pours a slightly hazy amber color with a thin off white head.  Aroma is esters and banana.  Flavor is yeast and banana.  Medium body.  Nice beer.  Thanks Shane.

Lightly hazy copper with a large head. Aroma of bananas and biscuits. More than a bit of white wine.  Taste is balanced between sweet malts and acidic belgian yeast style. And always bananas shine through.  Another great brew from Victory.

UPDATED: OCT 25, 2014 Bottle.  Sweet yeast-and-candis aroma, spicy cloves, bubblegum, and wheat, only light bubblegum.  Very malty with some sticky fruitiness and alcohol.  Cloudy amber-brown gradient with an ephemeral light brown head (more Bock than Weizen), big legs, and lots of sediment.  Crisp, sharp beginning, warming, lightly harsh end.  Quick tongue-buzz.  Taste is sweet malt with caramel, yeast, and a touch of dark earthiness to be detected underneath the cloves and light banana.   Lots of wheat flavor.  Alcohol does play a major role here (though Id only peg it at around 6% from taste).  Body is medium but very sticky-creamy, at times gives the impression of much more fullness.  Good deal of tang and light acidity, no real hop count, but a good balance on the whole.  Texture and mouthfeel are just fantastic here, but the carbonation could still be backed off a bit more.  Great smooth sipper, and great to style - a true, flavorful blend of a Dunkelweizen and a dark Bock - hair below the Schneider.  [2007.01.18: 3.8]Well, maybe more than a hair, but still holds up -- one of Victorys stronger offerings, to be honest, and thankfully doesnt shy from the bitterness to slop on more sugar.  An occasional delight! [2014.10.25: 3.8]

Pours a hazy brown with a dense 1/4 inch head. Some light lacing. Smells of ripe banana and sweet spice.

Taste is dominated by the ripe rich banana with the underpinnings of sweet spice. Alcohol is evident in the taste. Body is not overly sweet and sticky. Really tasty, great example of the style especially for an American brewery.

Bottled Aug. 2006. Pours a hazy copper-orange color with a thin, light tan head which fades out quickly. Candy-like aromas of Juicy Fruit gum, caramel covered apples and ripe banana are noted with mild fresh yeast and hot dinner rolls lurking in he background. Pleasant, full, round mouthfeel with just the right amount of tingly carbonation for the style. Taste is sweet, reminiscent of banana-nut bread, caramel apple, crystal malts, fresh yeast and mild spices. Finishes with the slightest presence of hop bitterness to tame any cloyishness. 8.7% ABV is non-detectable; very smooth and stealth. A well done domestic reproduction of the style.

UPDATED: MAR 1, 2007 Bottled (Thanks Dennis Bell)  Reddish Coppery pour with thin head. A hint of spice and malt can be detected and a small tone of fruit. (Possibly banana). Taste of Malt and some hop and spice. It was good but I expected better.

On tap in Carroll Gardens (Brooklyn) NY.  I loved this beer!  Loved the smoothness and finish, along with the hints of banana.  No idea it was 8.7% until I read about it here.  Very drinkable, wish I could find it in more places.
Very enjoyable weizen here.  Yet another finely crafted and authentic German-style offering from Victory.  Their "continental" beers are outshining their more "American" offerings these days...

12 oz bottle from Shadey.  Smell is bananas and some spice.  Pour is a dark amber/brown.  Nice amount of carbonation.  Taste is not overly complex, but pretty true to form.  Im surprised by the alcohol content here, because this is actually pretty drinkable.  nice beer.

UPDATED: DEC 21, 2006 12 oz. bottle: Initial aroma of berries, bananas and yeastiness.  Poured a  dark amber color with minimal head.  Tasted somewhat like bananas and spices.  Very malty.  As the beer warmed up, the aroma swayed toward the yeastiness, smelling like musty bread.  Smooth palate with lower than average carbonation.  Finished moderately with spices and yeast.  The alcohol is very well hidden in this relatively strong brew.  This beer changed quite a bit as it warmed up and I think I preferred it slightly colder.  I personally liked the initial aroma much better and this could have done with more head.  Otherwise, a very solid offering from Victory.

On tap @ Coles. Buffalo, NY. Not a  big fan of bananas so this rating may come in low. Very distinctive tastes & drinkable. Probably would have been better off not reading the discription on Victory.com before actually trying the beer
Banana bread in a beer.  Great tastes and aromas.  A very enjoyable drinkable bock beer.  You can hardly tell its 8.7% ABV.
very good beer, its sure tasted nice - the 8.7 is hidden nicely.  Definately a winner from victory

Have a few too many of these and the cats are all in danger.
Nice head, color, taste and results to my mood.

Bottle from JHop.  Pours dark amber, clear, with a spare off-white fizzy head and spare lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (caramel, cookie, nutty), average hops (flowers, perfume), average yeast (dough, earth) with notes of light alcohol, apple and smoke.  Average duration, moderate sweetness with heavy acidity and bitterness.  Medium bodied, alcoholic texture, lively carbonation.

Very enjoyable.  Great color but poured with very little head which disappeared in seconds.  Smells excellent, like a good hefe only thicker and maltier.  Taste is very pleasant with a bit of underlying acidity that keeps it interesting.

a muddy pour w/ hints of mahogony and a nice tall well laced tan head.  Aroma of sweet carmels some dark fruits definate plums a spicy like yeast definate wheat notes and a light alcohol.  Palate is nicely coated lightly creamy well carbonated, quite nice.  Flavor is nicely fruity plums and figs and a nice amount of carmel quite sweet lingering malty flavor w/ hints of a light spice from the yeast and a fair alcohol kick.  Very good stuff.
Reddish Brown in color with a huge huge head.  Left nice lacing too.  Aromas were spicy and malty.  Very spicy flavor with some fruity citrus too.  Reminded me how much I like a good Weizenbock.

Very red in color bordering on brown with an uninspiring, thin head for style that is orange in cast.  Lots of fake tasting banana extract in the nose that reminds me of Circus Peanut candy.  There is also a strong solvent-like character in the aroma that smells like nail polish remover.  Underneath though, there is some good malt.  Flavor is quite similar to the aroma which is disappointing.  I like Victory very much as a brewery, but I have not had a wheat beer from them to date that is worth a shit.  For me, this is a failure.
UPDATED: AUG 25, 2015 Bottle. Very good. Quite strong and very esthery. An excellent beer for late fall/ early winter.

One bottle from JB.  Cloudy apple cider looking ale with a small head. Fruity aroma, yeast, clove, spicy with banana esthers. Sweet wheat flavors with nice yeast profile, clove and banana. Smooth medium to full bodied. Very enjoyable!  Thanks JB
Pours a bright to dark amber into a Weizen.  Head quickly recedes to nothing.  Spicy clove, wheat and malt aromas.  Fizzy and malty with a lasting lemon wheat finish.

Wow.  This stuff rocks!  Apple, pumpkin, yeast waft from a dark hazy cider-colored beer with a thin head.  The palate is sour with banana taste and some sweetness.  Enough hops so it isnt cloyingly sweet.  Carbonation is also noticeable in the palate.  I love this brewer.
Pours a rich golden amber with minimum head that wisps away.  Distinct Weiss brew with bock body.  Yeasty with blended alcohol notes.  Commercial description is rather accurate.  Very enjoyable.

Pours a nice deep murky amber with a nice tan head. Slightly earthy aroma with a sweet bubblgum aspect and a light tartness. Beautiful creamy body, thick and smooth. Nice warmth and chewy maltyness. Slight spicyness, peppery alcohol hint with a fruity dryness in the finish.
brewtopia 10/21/06.  I swore this beer was made with brettanomyces, but now I am thinking the sourness was uninentional.  Tasted like a standard weizenbock that was contaminated.
On tap at Ds.  Hazy amber body.  Aroma is slightly sweet and fruity with a bit of straw and yeast.  Flavor is lightly spicey, wheaty, yeasty.  Alcohol is very well hidden.

UPDATED: JAN 3, 2007 Ah...the color of pepsi..but a bit more brown...creamy as hell...nice dense foam head that dissipates to a centimeter after settling....yum toasty malt flavor and clove ....easy to drink brew

UPDATED: JUL 11, 2008 Smell is sort of slight fruity bread yeast.  On tasting, it has a deceptively smooth start (for the alcohol rating) and the finish is slightly differently revolting yet appealing and desirable. How can that be? Had a high SAE ratiing for beer viscosity in my three stooges glass. Be careful drinking these, way to easy.

text: Draught sample at Union Beer Trade Tasting, NYC. Nice reddish-orange colour with a small orangish head. Aroma of wheat and yeast, with some herbal hops in behind. Soft, almost creamy mouthfeel. Very pleasant flavour - nice weizen character with a warm, spicey finish. Tasty!
From Kazanskys in Squirrel Hill, Pittsburgh. Bottle. Pours opaque caramel, thin off white head. Aroma is fruit, malt, spices. Flavor is fruit, malt, metallic, slight banana.

UPDATED: JUL 14, 2007 Bottle - Brown, cloudy pour with light foamy head.  Sugary-banana aroma that is quite appetizing.  Sweet, wheaty, with banana-spice-malt and smooth taste that finishes without much hint of alcohol.  This is another good one from Victory.

Botlle.2005.Pours dark cloudy amber , very large rocky tanned head. Sweet,milky malty aroma with light aromatic hop presence. Tofee like malt at background. Clean soft, weet maltey character with alcohol in the finish. Big beer that is pleasant to drink.

Aroma reminds me of a strong old ale, lots of fine hops combined with rich malts, murky brown, zero head. Big malt flavour start, caramel and treacle, loads of hops too. Full bodied, well balanced, bitter, dry and warming at the finish. Terrific! Thanks Radek!

UPDATED: APR 13, 2007 Cloudy dark amber with decent head. Smells like those sugary little "circus peanut" candies. Yeah, thats weird, but a nice sweet aroma. A bit too sweet to have very much. A little banana and maybe some pineapple makes it sound overly fruity, but its not. Just too sweet....good on first impression. But, the more I drink of it, the less I like it.

(Bottle 35,5 cl) Clear, dark amber with an off-white head. Rich aromas with lots of banana, yeast and alcohol - also some almost vinous touches. Fairly solid body with lots of fruit - banana in particular - and a rich, alcoholic finish. Lovely. 290806

A hazy orange beer with an orange head. The aroma is sweet orangy, combined with light notes of wheat and alcohol. The flavor is sweet malty with lots of caramel as well as light notes of wheat, that gives it a dry end, but it also has light spicy notes. The alcohol, that sets in from the middle gives the warmth.

UPDATED: AUG 31, 2006 Bottled. Clear light amber coloured. Light beige dense head. Sweetness, alcohol, fruits and light spice in the nose. Flavour is very alcoholdense with yeasty, sweet fruitynotes. Very light spiced. Medium bodied. Is very alcoholdense and warming in the end. A bit too much for me, but thanks anyway goes to Probiere for the trade.
Bottled. Pale amber coloured. Soap, alcohol and yeast in the aroma. Very sweet but light flavour. Alcoholic and bland.

(bonus brew from someone)cloudy orange/amber body with a small light brown head.aroma is a nice mix of apples,cinnamon,yeast,and wheat.flavor mixes up the same elements with a nice medium mouthfeel.really reminds me of a nice belgian dubble.

Oh nice.... Pours hazy dark muddy brown into the glass, with a very nice head and 1/8th-in. retention all the way down - leaves webbed lace.  Very nice caramel and toffee notes to the nose.  Caramel, banana (bread), toffee, sweet wheaty malts.  The finish feels of walnuts and bread.  With a syrupy mouthfeel, I can truly say that this brew is uniformly put together quite well.  The higher alcohol is well-integrated and only shows up "after" the finish.  TrevorFloyd (below) had it spot on.... it is like drinking banana bread.  Kudos to Victory on this one!

Wasnt impressed the first time I had it, but now Im hooked. It really is like drinking banana bread, but with a little more power in the flavor. Perfect drink to get you in the autumn mood. Before I thought it was one of Victorys few weak spots; now I think its another of their greats.

Bottled Aug 25, 2005. 

This smells like cloves and sweet bananas, tastes like spice bread. Really pretty beer, the lack of filtration gives a nice orange clody hue.  

Tastes great, although heavier than I was expecting, a fine bock. 

Wow, I can feel the heat in my stomach from the ABV on this one.
Sweet banana aroma.  Poured a hazy dark orange.  Had a sweet banana flavor, citrus. Felt thick on the palate.

bottle obtained in a trade with kramer17801.  Pours a hazy, light brown color with small head and small amount of sticky lacing.  Aroma is banana and spices with a slight malt hint at the end, very suprising and enjoyable on the nose.  Flavor is wheat and spice with banana bread hints through-out.  Not like i expected at all, but very enjoyable.  Very confusing combination, but it really works with this beer.

Bottle.  Pours a caramel color with a beige head.  Nose is bready, banana, roasty.  Flavors is almost like dulce de leche, but not as sweet, with slight banana and spice.  I like this one, great, creamy and mouth coating.  Flavors are individually subdues but make a luscious combination when juxtaposed as they are.
Pours a hazy brownish amber color.  Aromas of clove, banana, fruit, and alcohol.  Flavor is alcoholic clove and spice with a bittersweet finish.  Good beer, just not something I would have often.

Smells good, like warmed berries and sweet malt.  Mmm.  Lasting white head, hazy orange-brown colour.  Very carbony palate(the bottle exploded on maniac), but nice flavour with alcohol aftertones.  Overall quite enjoyable, could do with a touch less alcohol.
Hazy light brown body with a thick creamy light tan head. Aroma of banana and lots of spice. Sweet flavor, light banana, some fruit, and some spice.

UPDATED: NOV 12, 2006 Poured murky brownish in color, nice initial off-white head, decent lacing for a beer of this style and abv. The aroma was bubblegum, strong cloves, light bananas and other fruit esters. The flavor was bubblegum, cloves (some light peppers too), roasted bananas, vanilla, but also a light funky plastic, chemical, or fusel aftertaste. Tilted a little too far to the sweet and hot side of things, but not cloying or too sharp. Mouthfeel is moderate for the style.
UPDATED: JAN 22, 2007 Dark red coloring. Wheaty, full and  explodes with flavor. Flavor is fruity and a real delight.

Bottle, from trade with kramer17801. Bottled 8/25/05. Good nose, yeasty. Sweet, spice. Banana, clove, bubblegum, hints of the abv. Cloudy, but full sediment got poured in, orangy brown color. Good head, so-so lacing. Bittersweet flavor, like aroma. Its got a little zing to it. Medium body, creamy mouthfeel, sweet finish. I can see why some like it, but it lacked carbonation. Havent explored the world of Weizen Bocks too much so I dont know if its suppose to be that way.

text: Thanks for the bottle Kevin! Best before date a year past. Deep orange pour with a thin white froth. Looks to have lost some life. Lots of spicy fruit in the aroma, some prunes, plums and malt.  Sweet and spicy, lots of malt, but watery in the finish, and not as tasty as expected. Age wast too kind to this one!

Bottle. Pours a hazy orange body with some small floaties and no head. The aroma has some sweetness along with orange citrus hops, fruit, and some alcohol. Caramel-sweet, rich malt flavours in a moderately alcoholic body. Somewhat disappointing flavour profile...Im pretty sure this was an older bottle and it was decent but Id like to try it fresh(er).
UPDATED: APR 26, 2006 Bottle sampled with Stegosaurus. Pours bronze with an off-white head. Aroma of citrus, wheat, spices, and caramel malts. Flavor is alcohol, citrus, wheat, banana-like. Nice.

Bottle from 08.25.05 - pours out dark brown with a huge tan head.  Smells malty, sweet, yeasty, and pretty damn good.  Taste is very similar, with a slight taste of hop implanted into every sip.  Has an over all fruity taste too.  Went pretty good with some country style steak.  Not bad.

Bottled 8/25/05. A little dated; not sure how well this style does with age. Authentic German weizenbock aroma. Wheat and apricot. Reddish amber body with a large tan head and yeast floaties. Murky.  Tastes pretty much how it smells. A lively carbonation that is a subtle zing at the back of the tongue. Hints of banana, but they are quickly overpowered by malt and alcohol. The alcohol is not overly noticeable at the first few sips, but it catches up. Im trying to decide if this is more than just a dark wheat with extra alcohol or if it is more carefully crafted. I do like it and would welcome the opportunity to try a fresher bottle, served perhaps a little colder.
Pours orange-amber with a lot of sediment.  Sweet, fruity aroma of cherry, peach, pears, and apple.  Flavor is really sweet, although it turns out well balanced.  Wheaty, smooth and delicious.

Bottle  Pours a murky amber with a fizzy light brown head.  Head produces good lacing but diminishes quickly.  Has a fruity aroma with touches of spice.  Has a decent carbonation.  A thin texture.  Has decent finish thats not traditionally bitter but very good.  A pretty good duration.  The flavor has a very good mix.  I like this one.  Its fruity but smooth.  Well done.

Just inching over the half-way mark at twenty-two.  Put simply: Weizen Bocks are good.  Apple and pear cobbler.  Sweet and juicy.  Some banana bread as well.  Alcoholic pepperiness in the finish.  I wonder if Victory ever considered forming an Eisbock out of this.  As if I need more alcohol in my beer.

Ive had this the last 3 years running. The 2003-04 were not that impressive. Malty fruity beers with a thicker mouthfeel. The 2005 was differant. Had the same qualities as past years but with a BIG banana Bread presence. That IMO makes a world of differance.
amazingly dope, a pleasure to drink, alcohol very well hidden, fruitiness done well taste of cherries, brightened my day

Thanks to SpringLicker for this one.  12 0z bottle, enjoy by 4/05.  Nice looking beer.  Big carbonation on a copper pour.  Medium frothy head.  Heffeweizen like aroma.  Banana clove and light hops that give it some crispness and spiciness.  The taste is spicy ginger, pepper and hints of banana cake.  Lightly malty but in a fresh way (wheat I assume).  Warm alcohol.  Very light hints of sweetness like you might get from Belgian hard candy.  Slick medium body and a round mouth feel.  Not a favorite of mine, but not too bad.

12 oz bottle.  Pours a cloudy chestnut color with a fluffy one finger sized beige head.  No visible carbonation.  Aroma is just bursting with fruity esters, its like banana bread in a glass.  Notes of bubblegum, caramel, candied dark fruits, and a hint of alcohol.  Spicy and fruity flavor with banana, caramel, chewy wheat and light alcohol.  Finish is fruity and yeasty.  Lively and fizzy carbonation that cuts thru the thick cloying malty base prepping your palate for the next sip.  A nice chewy Weizenbock with lots of flavor, one of my favorite seasonals from Victory.

Bottled Aug O5. Pours hazy reddish brown with tan diminshing head. Wonderful fruity aroma of banana and cherry lifesavers. Flavor of dark wheat malt, citrus, and a hint of caramel. Alcohol is well hidden, though I pick up a tad amount in the otherwise sweet and yeasty finish. I cant believe how well this held up. This is a great domestic wheat beer. I am a fan of Victory, but this one really surprised me, as I am really picky about my wheat beers.

Bottle courtesy of jjpm74. Thanks John! Bottled on Aug 25.05. Poured a hazy brown with a big tan head that settled quickly. Sweet fruity aroma with banana, raisin, and cherry picked out. A sweet dark fruit flavor with spices and hint of malts. Medium thick body. Very enjoyable!!
Oh sweet goodness, this beer is delicious.  Sweet aroma, bold smooth taste that goes down easy.  Excellent.  This beer is refreshing to my palate.  As Joe would say... COWBOYS, LIGHT YOUR FIRE!
pours hazy caramel color nice compact off-white head, aroma of citrus, spices, and caramel malts. flavor is alcohol packed, citrusy,banana-like, smooth great blend, good body, great brew.

12oz bottle - pours a rich, hazy mediun brown with a very creamy, three finger tan head, that hangs around a long time. Aroma is full of sweet malt, dark fruit and clove. The taste is nicely complex, with an array of sweet fruit, malt and caramel. There are also very subtle hints of several spices that were hard for me to ID. The alcohol comes to the front now and then but in a nice way. Mouthfeel is a bit fizzy but rich and smooth as well. Aftertaste is long and offers some notes of yeast and sweet malt. This is a very nice, easy drinking beer, even with a fairly high dose of alcohol. I like it!

This is a unique German beer style, that is a wheat bock. This style of beer is very similar to dunkle hefeweizen, in that it is an ale, it is brewed with a significant portion of wheat malt, along with some dark malts, and it is bottle conditioned. The yeast strain used in this beer, is the Weihenstaphan strain, which is used in brewing classic Bavarian hefeweizen. Where it differs is that it has the alcohol strength of a bock beer, around 7-8% abv. 

Moonglow pour to a murky deep caramel color with a huge, thick, rocky head, and a very lively carbonation. The nose is superb on this beer. Aromas of clove, banana, and ripe fruit marry with sweet malt aroma, and peppery waves of alcohol. The palate is very complex with just layers of flavor. Sweet malt, a touch of caramel, pear, perhaps, some melon, and subtle hints of spice all slide over the tongue. This beer finishes with more good malt flavors up front, then ends with that classic spicy clove/bubble gum yeast character that is signature of the Weihenstaphan strain. 

This is an outstanding domestic example of a classic German beer style.

Bottle from Slob  Thanks! 
Pours a rich, cloudy cola-brown with a frothy cream head.  Aroma is thin and spikey, with hints of wheat, yeast, and malt.  Flavor is a rush of pear, spice, and a bit of citrus/honey in the finish.  Perhaps a smidgen of bubblegum in there as well.  Palate slips along the tongue at a leisurely pace, sure, but whats the hurry?  Im enjoying every sip of this one.

text: Bottle.  Bubblegummy wheat, grainy hearty aroma.  Red brown with a fizzy beige head.  Tinny vegetable flavor, yuck.  Seems I dont like the weizenbock style so much?

Aroma is full of ripe fruit, much like a dubbel.        Pours lighter than its kin (Aventinus), with a moderate but quickly disappearing head.  Flavor is mostly tart apple, with the expected bock sweetness.  Finish is surprisingly dry, with the wheat left on your tongue.
smell and taste of cloves, appearance is dark copper, has a nice feel in mouth.  I think I prefer the normal wizen style

UPDATED: AUG 9, 2008 As the name would suggest, this is the bastard child of a doppelbock and a weissbeer.  Pours amber.  Combines the best aroma and flavor elements of wheat beers and doppelbock- aromas include citrus, yogurt, and alcohol.  Slightly sweet, slighlty bitter.  Now if only this stuff was available year-round...
I like this beer.  It has tons of fruit and citrus character.  Also pours a huge malty head.  Incredibly smooth and it is a 8.7 wheat beer.  COOL!

12oz bottle shared by joshuaB. Pours a hazy orange color with a white receeding head. Nose is lemony, bananay, fresh and sweet malt. Flavors of banana, more lemon, some bubblegum, more fresh outdoorsy very clean flavors. Finishes lightly bitter.

thanks to richlikebeer for this. poured cloudy orange, with a white head that didnt last. aroma yeast, hops malts, lemon, a mild sourness. flavor lemon pops its head up first than got malt and hops a nice touch of alcohol, fruity. a nice way to start the drinking for New Years Eve.

Poured a cloudy dark amber...minimal head.  Light malt nose with some sweet fruit (banana) and caramel notes.  More malt in the taste, some pear, yeast, toffee.  Some bitter spiciness in the end.  Tasty.

Bottled on Apr 4/0/5. Fruity aroma along with grain and sour. Deep orange color body with decent head. Flavor of sourness, tangy oranges and syrpy. Smooth beer but the alcohol is little overwhelming inn this brew. Had this after a day of drinking swill at the Redskins/Carinals football game.

Fully hazy orange-amber, very carbonated; orange-yellow head, fast reduced to 1/2 cm. Orange peel and alcohol nose, mandarines. Caramel, caramelised fruit (oranges, plums), lots of alcohol, a few earthy notes, toffee and, again mandarine flavour. Slick & alcoholwarming, give it one hell of a smooth feeling. Not fizzy as expected, just a little burning and sourish lining. Yeast filling. Nice  - very unlike any Weizenbock tried so far. Thanks to BrianB!

Quite good!  Pours a dark brown, with a tinge of red, nice short head, perfect for a wezenbock.  Fruity yet wheat-beerish aroma, very nice.  Nice and thick, with a great flavor of bananas that have turned a little ripe, lots of syrup qualities in this one.  Overall, and enjoyable weizenbock.

Bottle from axilla; bottled on Aug 25, 05.  Thanks much!  The beer pours to a really hazy, likely murky amber bronze body with a thick, dense, and creamy beige head.  The aroma is hugely banana and wheat bread.  It smells so much like fresh bananas, its insane.  Its like bananas were used in the fermentation.  Theres also some light yeasts and vanilla.  Can you say banana bread?  Unreal!  The flavor is dramatically different from the aroma.  I dont get any banana in the flavor.  Instead, I get a toasted malt and light clove.  Thinking to recent wheat-based beers, its like they used the toasted sprouts from Bells wheat series, but left a lot of the other stuff out.  Light spices and ever so light rauch smokeyness.  Malty, yes.  Distinguished, no.  But, still, it is good.  Anyway, the palate is moderately thick and creamy.  Feels pretty good and goes down smoothly.  Lightly chewy.  A good brew from Victory!  As it warms, the flavor improves enough to re-rate.

A unique beer.  Ive never had a beer in which the alcohol played such a prominent role in the development of the flavor profile, instead of working against it.  Very interesting stuff.  The typical wheat beer characteristics (bready, yeasty, banana, spice) ride on top of the alcohol.  Also has a distinct sticky sweetness to it.  Very nice, quality beer perfect for the fall season.

A deep, copper/caramel with opaque hazing and a thin, tan film after a soda-pop fizz-down. Aroma was a full frontal assault of clove oil and ripe banana... sour & bready with rum notes. Alcohol turns overbearing late. Richly flavored with lingering clove over a stable wheat base. Creamy in the mouth with lilting spiciness to finish and pleasant smokiness throughout. Many more complexities than I was expecting.

A walk on the wild side. I found this beer in the "Bargain Bin" of a store that may not have actively carried it for years. A fun surprise though. Pours a soup murky apple cider and cherry juice pour, with flecks of light and dark yeast. Head is tall and orange tinted. Aroma is reserved, yet loaded with fresh warm alcohol, over french pears sauteed with butter. Theres a bready yeast background, typical of the style. Flavor is interesting, a rich strong run of bright fruit alcohol, followed by a mouthful of warm bread, sugary malt and spicy yeast. The beer almost starts out like a tart fruit beer, with some of those sour notes, but then moves into the typical cloying wheat and bock characters. Very intersting. I think this beer has really picked up something with time. Delicious. The alcohol is a little hot right of the bat, but also really carries the beer. I dont really detect any off notes, just some really matured flavors, nothing indicative of oxidation or being light struck. Palate lacks a little as it runs off fast, but leaves a burnt sugar appeal at the end.
Pours a dark amber with a big beige head.  Flavor is sweet and fruity. A very different style of beer but worth a try.

A murky, fruity, deceptively strong brew and a favorite of mine. The aroma mixes dark malt, clove, mysterious spices and a bit of citrus. The flavor is similar, with a slight tartness that is perfect for these fall evenings.

Murky rusty brown, with some light tan head. Nose is wheat, alcohol, spice, and some dark malts. Taste begins very malty, with a nice touch of sweetness. Next, wheat pushes the malt aside to become the other major element. Peaches peaches and peaches, oh my, what a nice touch. Also making an appearance, are spices, apples, and brown sugar. Bananas and light hops linger on the tongue, with only the slightest tinge of EtOH. Never too sweet. Deceptively dangerous at 8.7%, as this stuff seems to go down quickly. The first time Victory has impressed me. Worthy as an Aventinus competitor.

Thanks to gputty for this Victory. pours a cloudy brown, off white head. Fruity nose, hops and wheat present, too. Wonderful flavor, more of the wheat comes through as it warms. I could drink quite a bit of this (but the 8.7% may catch up quickly).
Pour is a very murky brown with a white head.  Aroma is vanilla and bananas.  Flavor is sweet banana bread with a touch of cinamon on top.  A very different style of beer but worth a try.
Pours a dark amber with a big bubbley beige head. Aroma is loads of bananas and spice, some citrus notes. Flavor is very fruity, bready, slightly sour in the finish.  Sparkling, champagne mouthfeel.
This was huge disappointment for me, being a huge fan of Aventinus. Another reason for me to skeptical of US microbrewery specialty beers.

Bottle via trade with Dickinsonbeer.  Murky orange color with a tan colored head.  Aromas of bananas.  Flavor is made up of bananas, bread, orange juice and some mulling spices.  Very viscous mouth feel.

On tap at Firkins, Libertyville, IL.  Cloudy amber hued having lasting large creamy white head with good lacing.  Intoxicating aroma of swirling spices and fruity esters.  No discernable carbonation.  Medium-to-full bodied that starts with tart, sweet malt flavor with touches of spices and banana and finishes dry with slight bitterness. Enjoyed  the day after the White Sox won the World Series. GO WHITE SOX! Awesome tasty and memorable beer.

Ive given this a few bottles worth of evaluation before adding a rating, and in the end I have to say--it just has this acerbic, sour note that doesnt agree with me.  Maybe some citrus qualities that dont mesh with the banana-nut bread parts?  Theres also other fruit in here too, figs and some dates probably.  Some hoppiness as well, but the hop aromas dont really mesh that well with the hefe yeast phenols.  So.  Yes.  I cant rave about this as much Id like to.

Acquired in a trade from BA Px2GrafX, the beer poured out murky amber brown in color with a rich creamy head typical of most Weizen biers. The looks were like a Weizen concentrate, and so was the smell. The smells of banana and clove were found here with a pungency that other Weizens rarely ever exhibit. The taste was again very similar to a hyper Hefeweizen, with every phenolic element present, but only more so. Reminiscent of liquefied banana nut bread with spices, this beer went down very easily with not a single hint of the high ABV content. To add an American twist to the style, a definite hop bitterness was detectable towards the end of each swallow. Carbonation was extremely fine and gave this a creamy mouthfeel. What a dangerously drinkable beer! I can see this one getting someone is trouble quite easily, as it packs quite a punch that you can never see coming. Quite different from Aventinus, as this is more Weizen than Bock.

Ah, a wheat beer that a stout/barleywine drinker like myself can really enjoy. I usually find wheat beers too light for my taste, although I love sniffing them. This beer isnt light, which is good, and its crispness keeps it from tasting heavy. I could just smell this beer all night (if someone could bottle just the scent, Id spray it all over my wife): I get banana and clove, maybe pear, ginger and taffy. Where most wheat beers let me down when I go from smelling to tasting, this beer comes through with concentrated flavors, so what you smelled is what you get. I could not detect the strong alcohol in the flavor. I really liked this beer, but at $12 (with tax) for a six pack, the price is prohibitive, and I wont be buying it again for a long time. Purchased at West Lakeview Liquors at Addison and Leavitt, my new favorite local liquor store for good deals on rare stuff.
cloudy dark amber w/ huge huge head.  (like kylas) sweet and fruity and pretty drinkable.

LvBrewfest.  A nice wheat and spicy aroma.  Pour was a clouded orange. Flavor was fruit filled happiness, banana, orange and spices. Palate was surprisingly light considering the appearance.  Overall I really liked it.

Big nose: wheat and berry, as well as clovey spices. Cloudy crap-brown with a tall foamy head. Cherry malt flavors, sugary sweet. With the wheat base, its like a cookir. Light spicey end. Silky smooth and heavy. Alcohol warms slightly going down, especially through the glass.

Excellent strong wheat brew. Muddy orange/brown in color.   Long-lasting, frothy head is very appealing.  Banana with orange spice and alcohol are  the primary smells.   Taste is a thinner version of forward aromas.  Finishes a little alcoholy, but smooth.  Very good fall brew.

UPDATED: NOV 29, 2005 Delivered direct to my house from Downingtown, PA c/o my roommate’s very generous dad. Thanks!! Pours dark hazy amber with a mostly maintained tan head. Aroma of spicy yeast, banana, clove, oranges, caramel, and dark fruits. Taste is initially sweet with spicy clove, but finishes with fruity esters and mellow wheat. Mouthfeel is medium bodied with lush carbonation. Despite still being a young beer (bottled 8-9-05), the alcohol has mellowed impressively after only two months of cellaring.  A delightful nightcap beer. Quite delicious, but still a couple notches below Aventinus.
Another rock steady Victory offering. Caramel grainy taste with medium body. Surprising body considering the alcohol.  There is a bitter apple spice component mixed in.

Appears a caramel color with a 1 finger off white head. Some spotty lacing is left behind.
Smell is of banana, wheat, caramel, and chocolate.
Taste is of the same aromas that has been watered down slightly.
Mouthfeel is fizzy, full bodied, and sweet.
Drinkability is good. Im a big fan of the style and I like Victorys version.

Sweet vinuous malty aroma, brown sugar, sour wheats and estery yeasty goodness. Decent aroma. Cloudy dark amber, small chunks on bottom, with thin foamy lacing head. Medium body with medium-high carbonation, almost effervescent. Starts with decent wheaty sweet malt taste. Brown sugar, light caramel, medium floral bitterness. A bit watery, but once it warms its a pretty decent weizenbock.

Pours a deep orange with almost no head. The aroma is overwhelmingly cinnamon, spicy, cider, apples. Taste carries over the cinnamon to a wonderful degree, along with pumpkin, malts, slight bitterness, perfectly balanced. A perfect October beer.

Reddish brown body with a huge head. It even spilled a little out of my stupid Leute Bokbier glass... but I wasnt really paying attention either. Banana, caramel come out in aroma and flavor. Can taste some alcohol in there too, but its not enough to be bad. Very wheaty feel to it. I dont understand how I enjoyed this so much less than Mahrs, which is rated about a 3.5 on here.... rerate pending for that I guess.

Draft, Baja Bean, Staunton VA. Murky amber brown color thinning at the edges; looks like fresh apple cider. Incredible esters: bubblegum, apple, orange and lemon citrus, wet grass, yeast, gym sock funk, and an overall rotten sourness much like red apples beginning to go bad; perfect fall aromas. Medium to full body, full and smooth mouthfeel, flavors of all of the above wrapped up nicely in an overall yeasty malt sweetness. Sweet and sour aftertaste. The alcohol is well masked but provides a nice warmth, escpecially in the finish. Cant say enough about this one, I loved it!
Very nice indeed. Sweet banana, some cinnamon, all yeasty and such. 8.7%? Wow, it will catch up to you, but a pleasure to drink. Only quibble- the carbonation is a wee bit too much.

Huge cushy white pillow of a head on this murky brown and thick brew. Vanilla, yeast, banana and cinnamon - very intense in nose and taste. Like a banana bread. Loveable silky mouthfeel -  bit too sweet all in all for my preferences and I would say nearly overdone for this Style.

On draft.  Pours a hazy apple cider color leaving a thin head.  Aroma is of banana esters.  Flavor also exhibits bananas and other spicy flavors.   Pretty tasty although I wouldnt drink this one all night.  Unique and quite tasty though.

Pours a very hazy bubbly brown with a large amount of frothy offwhite manilla head.  Aroma is malt, yeast, spices, and alcohol.  Flavor is in some ways light and sweet, others biting and harsh alcohol.  Really a weird beer to try.  Overall, just so so.
Draft at Ginger Man, NY. Hazy copper color with moderate white head that diminished slowly. Solid wheat and fruit aroma. Medium body. Good complex flavor with a long smooth finish. Very good brew.
Pours a dark cloudy orange with a thin white head. Aroma is mostly yeast with some malt and spices. Has a nice well balanced, smooth, and crisp flavors of yeast, malt, fruit, pine, and spice.

Marginal small-bead head on a deep, hazy, rich orange-brown beer.  Aromas are peach, apple cider, cinnamon, cardamom, and some crystal malts.  Light-to-medium and creamy on the palate, with a long, easy finish of cider and pear -- a lot like a mellow kriek with the yeast and fruit.  Flavors are gentle but fruit-forward, with a nice spice background and well-hidden alcohol.  A unique and tasty beer for late fall.

Sampler (then pint) from brewpub.  This is what I expect in a weizenbock.  Nice and creamy mouthfeel with a decent amount of carbonation.  Phenolic and estery aroma and flavors from the hefeweizen yeast.  Brown and cloudy in appearance.  Overall, possibly my favorite Victory beer.

UPDATED: SEP 23, 2005 (12 oz bottles: Obtained in trades with jah noth, goldtwins and IMtheOptimator, thanks Dan, Larry and Andrew!) Ive collected four bottles of Moonglow in trades from sources in three different states because Ive had very bad luck with this beer.  All previous attempts to sample this beer from a bottle have been unsuccessful as each one was sour and presumably infected.  All have been aged for at least a few months, with this one being aged the least (4 months beyond the so-called expiration date).  This is the first bottle of this recently-acquired group and fortunately, its healthy and delicious.  It pours a bright ruddy amber color, and by swirling in all the yeast sediment, the beer is cloudy and translucent, so I can barely make out the carbonation bubbles rising to the surface.  The light-tan head doesnt pour terribly large, but it has settled at a thin, complete layer atop the beer, though it does eventually fade to a small ring.  The nose is very yeasty and estery, with some banana and a bit musty.  Wheat and esters first and foremost, sweet and caramely, some banana and bubble gum, a gentle tartness, and a hint of spiciness in the finish thats pretty unusual for the style.  There is also a mild bitterness in the finish, but Im less enthused about this development.  Eructation presents a massive blast of banana and bubble gum.  Body is medium-full, well-carbonated, somewhat dense and thick, but thanks in part to the gentle tartness, its not in syrupy or sticky, so maybe too, that mild bitterness in the finish is a good idea after all.  Well, even though it easily falls short of Aventinus (what doesnt?), this is very tasty, wonderfully authentic, and worth the effort to finally get some good bottles.  And Im very happy that I still have three more bottles in my cellar.

Bottle.  Bottled:  08/25/05.  Pours a thick, murky, diarrhea brown with a big, creamy dark-khaki head that leaves a thick ring of lace.  Wheaty, yeasty aroma with some lemony citrus, banana, apple cider and spicy notes.  The body is as thick as it sounded in the pour.  Wheat, yeast, lemon and banana in the forefront, followed by a very rich caramelly and estery maltiness.  Hints of dark fruits and pears.  Finishes with some spices and a big alcohol burn that dries the back of the throat.  This would be near perfect if they dropped the alcohol down just a tad.
Has a nice amber color.has a really nice sweetness to it. but it has some spice to it as well it is a very nice combination.

On tap at The Ginger Man, NYC.  Pours a cloudy brown color.  Intense apple aroma with mild notes of spice.  Medium bodied and smooth.  Heavy sweet flavoring of apple cider and candy (cotton candy possibly) with notes of alcohol and spice.  Unusual combination but somehow Victory makes it all work.  Very unique and quite good.
Cloudy amber,large beige head,intense bead.Light spicy pear,soft malt nose.Sweet wheat malt palate,with yeastiness and spice.Not bad, but not one of my favorite styles

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2006 On tap at Victory.  Pours an almost a cloudy brown, looked like apple cider with a small tan head.  Aroma of darker fruits and apple cider.  Initial taste is almost like cough syrup like.  Palate is very thick.  I think the initial cough syrup taste and feel may have been due to the cold temp it was served at and the thicker feel.  As it warmed up I actually started feeling more of an apple cider taste with an alcohol burn on the tongue.  Some citrus in the flavor as well.  6-4-6-3-14

Re-rate 10/14/2006. It has been a while since I last had this and my palate has expanded quite a bit.  This one deserves a re-rate.  Pours a hazy brown amber with an average light tan creamy lacing head that sustained.  Aroma of banana, yeast, malt, kind of spicy well done weizen bock.  Flavors of the same with some tart wheat, banana, citrus and toast.

Found this in the back of my frig so its aged a bit.  Very thin head that does cling to the side of the glass.  Fantastic fruity aroma., amber color, moderate body. Can taste the alcohol and a spicy end.  A very good beer!
Very hazy orangy amber with a good malty yeasty spicy banana aroma. Flavour is yeasty malty estery.

UPDATED: DEC 12, 2007 First Weizen Bock Ive had and I must say this is pretty interesting.  Has those fruity wheat beer notes but then some bite of a bock.  Alcohol is a little noticeable.  Definitely worth a try. 

Rerate:  still think the alcohol is very noticeable.  But some rich malts and yeast spices.  Really silky texture despite being super carbonated.

Pours a cloudy orange amber color with a thin white head. Very appealing aroma of fruits, bubblegum, wheat and spices. Very good flavor of candy, bubble gum, fruits, wheat and spices. The body is medium with a slick, creamy texture and moderate carbonation. This is a solid example of the style.
Fruity, spicy, cloudy amber. Very good aftertaste worked well with pizza. Above average for the little experience I have had with the style. Bit nauseating yeast.

Bottle.  Cloudy amber pour with decent head.  Usually nice balance of banans and cloves, though the last bottle I had was maybe a little old and a little winey.  Some nice spices in there too.  Enjoyable beer - but I wonder how well it will hold up in a cellar.

Cloudy reddish brown with smooth, cream head. The taste is like it might be a little old, but no one else commented on that. Caramel, cinnamon, old bananas and clove. Obviously a much bigger beer than a regular hefe.

12oz bottle. Enjoy by March 01 05. Ooops! Served @ 53° in my NB worthy glass. Pours orangish, golden maroon with a small, wispy head and finely ground pepper sized floaties. The aroma is sweet malt, bubblegum?, mild citrus and banana and a bit of spiciness. The initial taste is nearly candy like malt sweetness with some yeast notes and orange, banana, and coriander. The mid-taste is very citric; oranges and lemon really balance out the initial sweetness. The finish is spicy and a touch hot, but not badly so. The mouthfeel is substantial, with a nice slightly sour and spicy finish that also accentuates the yeast. This is a mighty fine beer.

2004 bottle sampled in 2005: Still orangish and cloudy with a tan head.  Some sediment is present, but not as much as in the 2003 bottle.  Smells of grapes and cherries with some nice cherry notes.  The banana is very faint, but still there.  Thick but semi-sweet and sugary mouthfeel.  Fig notes on the finish.</br>
</br>
2005 bottle sampled in 2005: Pours cloudy and brownish with a tan lasting head.  Smells of rasberries, sugar, and caramel.  Taste is of bananas, coriander, oranges, butterscotch, toffee.  Mouthfeel is full and bubbly with a nice lingering bubblegum aftertaste.  These continue to impress!

bottle, best by 4/5/05 - Cloudy amber with a nice fluffy head.  This is very aromatic!  I can smell it 2 feet away.  Yeastly, fruity aroma...apple.  This smells great.  Yeast flavors to start, dark fruits and apple also start out.  I also sense some bitter orange peel more toward the finish.  The wheat presence is evident also, along with a slight alcohol warmth.  This is a well balanced and very tasty brew.  I would say that it ages well.

12 oz bottle best by April 15 05 - Obtained in a trade from Bluedevil0206.  Thanks James - Pours cloudy murky amber color with a healthy 1/2 inch offwhite head.. Aroma is fruity, bannana apple cloves and yeast all fill the air above this one..  Flavor is a nice blend of cloves, bannana bread,  a touch of maple sweetness and honey come through as well.  On the palate this is quite smooth and refreshing...  Much character over a beautiful creamy body..  Finishes with a slight spice burn that is actually nice..  A very unique brew and one of the best of this style that Ive had..  Im amazed that is this 8.7% because I never would have guessed it as I was drinking it..  Another nice brew from a good brewer!

Cloudy apple cider looking ale with a small head. Fruity aroma, yeast, clove, spicy with banana esthers. Sweet wheat flavors with nice yeast profile, clove and banana. Smooth medium to full bodied. Very enjoyable!
user_location: Cape Coral Waterfront Wonderland, Florida, USA

text: dark orangy color. Smells yeasty and spicy-fruity with a sour touch and some cloves and bananas. Sweet and spicy flavor, with a nice prolonged aftertaste. I only recently got into german beers, so Im rather lacking in adjectives... I like it.

12oz bottle thanks to Pjones6738.   Aroma was earthy, nutty with clove and banana.  The clove spiciness really stands out.  Darker orange in color, almost amber.  Huge noisy/rocky head that diminshed in a few minutes.  Sweet malt at first, then some of the spice comes through but the finish is burnt popcorn and toasted wheat.  Medium body, creamy texture and I think the finish was dry, but I may have been thirsty.
Orange with a small off white head. Aroma is sour and yeasty with spices. The sourness in the aroma is not a pleasant one either. Flavor is sour, dry, and flat. Tastes quite wretched.

Ive been looking forward to this one.  Fiery, clouding orange/bronze with a booming foamy 4" head in my .5 L boot glass.  Holy banana aroma with spices: pepper, cloves, nutmeg and cinnamon.  Faint trace of tin as well.  Flavor is sweeter than expected with fruity banana smoothie tastes leading the way.  Sweet maple syrup over chocolate chip and banana pancakes.  Such a refreshing beer.  Imperial Hefe is a good description.  Were at 55 degrees and doing great.  Pepper clove finish.  Yum.  This one went way too fast.  If only Victory was distributed in Milwaukee.  Thanks to tpkenned for the bottle!
cloudy orange-copper and gold at edges.  quick tan head.  citrusy, lemony caramel and banana nose.  very citrusy lemon hop flavor, banana too.  dryish sour acidic finish.

bottle from brickskeller.  aroma: yeasty like a weiss should be.  color is cloudy light brown, small tan head.  flavor is great, sweet full bodied, but not overwhelming.  its no aventinus, but what is?

had this one with the ramstein winter wheat and what a difference. Just pouring this one after the ramstein was shocking.  much lighte color kind of a translucent orangish brown, with an off-white head,  fruity spicy wheaty flavor, seems almost lighter malts than some dunkels I"ve had.  not a bad beer, lighter than I expected but very drinkable.  I do like the imperial hefe description that really seems to hit it on the head.

Bottle Pours a hazy deep orange/amber with littel off white head that dissapears quickly.  Belgian yeast and light sweet malts are on the nose and not much hops.  Flavor is much the same, with a more fruity character.  Aples, appricots and bananas.  A soft, slightly cloudy feel and a soft carbonation.  The ABV is apparent but not out of line.

Bottle courtesy of BuckNaked in trade. Pours murky amber with little head. Aroma is strange smoky yeasty banana. Flavor has some banana, smoke, some kind of citrus, and I cant get past this smoke still. Decent overall.

Thanks to Zathrus13 for the bottle.  Pours an opaque dark orange.  Nice frothy white head.  Earthy, yeasty aroma, very wheaty.  Wheat, sweet nose melds into subtle fruit flavors, rather "banana and clove" like.  The finish brings the yeasty bite, very refreshing.  Alcohol character evident in the warmth experienced in the end of the finish.  The body is a medium smooth, especially considering the alcohol content.

A great trade with the Good Doctor (DocLoc).  A quick frothy off-white head that diminishes with no lacing.  Fizzy.  Slight grape aroma.  Clear copper.  Spicy biscuit and long lasting maltiness.  Excellent on the tongue.  Very quaffable for the style.  Not a lot of complexity.  Quite warming.

pours cloudy tan with a head the color of garlic cloves. aroma is fruity banana and some yeasty goodness with some bubblegum. tart sourness that is metallic. more banana comes through with some corriander in the finish. this really attacks my tongue, like little needles all over it. lingering pear taste. the alcohol really shows through in this one, and it does not compliment it. thanks to slob for this one.

A beautiful Orange color with a short lived tan head. Nice Clove, Banana scent with some fruit cocktail and yeasty tones. Lip smacking, sweet malt with wood and fruit. Alcohol follow but well masked. Reminds me somewhat of a mild Aventinus, good  but not in that hallowed beers league.

Bottle.  Coppery and not as hazy as I would have expected.  Good initial head, but then it disappears, never to return.  Good aroma: cloves, corriander, bubblegum, banana and some mustiness.  Citrus and dryness are the first aspects to meet your tongue.  Not too much, but noticeable.  Caramel appears as it warms as does a slight alcohol tingle (but youd never know its 8.7%)  It finishes dry with both a slght alcohol and some floral hops.  Its very good, but its made by Victory, what else did you expect?

Gold Brown Colorng with Sandy Skin. Heavy Particles in the Bottle.  Citrus Aroma.  Malty, Sweet, Fruity...Pretty Carbonated and Hoppy Ending. Something Ran Amuck in this Bottle.  Pretty Unbalanced and Not Drinkable.  Will Try Again in Hopes That Victory Wouldnt Punish Like This From Above in Such a Manner.

Hazy, dark red color with a thin head.  Aroma of sour bread.  Woah... it gets more sour and bitter in the taste, mixing with wheat and malt.  Its not a good sour like Gueuze, but more like an infection or staleness run amok.  I hope it was just a bad bottle.

Pours brown-ish color with light airy head which dissapates quickly.  Light, perhaps initially slightly metallic smell.  Great fruity/citrus/caramel taste which lasted forever after the sip was swallowed.  Delicious!

hazy copper, tight off white head.  aroma of yeast, jelly candies, caramel, bready malt and toast.  a littlealcohol in the flavour, dark wheaty malt, caramel, yeast, lemon, mixed berries.  mildly spicy tart finish.  not bad.

Pours a dark amber.  Reasonable head, but kinda fizzy and doesn’t coat the glass.  Coriander and orange peel aroma with the same in the taste.  Warming alcohol, but not overstated.  Very much like a New Belgium Tripel only cleaner and dryer in the taste.  Also far more pricey than the tripel, but nevertheless very good.

Bottle: Poured a deep amber looking beer that is clearly not filtered with a good size head with good retention. Aroma is light roasted malt with some cloves/cinnamon. Taste is quite enjoyable with the roasted aspect mixing quiet well with the spicy (cinnamon?) and banana taste. Some bitterness can also be noticed at the end with a medium to full body.

Bottle.  Pours out a nice hazy orange/amber color.  Creamy looking off-white head fades slowly to a ring and no significant lacing is left.  Aroma is pleasantly wheaty with lots of bananna and a touch of clove/yeast.  Body is medium.  Fairly smooth with a little burn on my sore throat.  Wheat beer flavors abound.  One of the better Victory products in my opinion.

Bottle:  Sweet fruity aroma with apple and banana.  Pours a hazy reddish-orange with slight tranparency.  Small white head.  Fruit (banana and apple) with a slightly sour finish.  Not bad, but just doesnt do much for me.

Bottle dated August 20, 2004.  Deep orange/amber in colour with a medium tan head.  The aroma was turning sour, still some malt and bananas but lots of vinegar.  The flavour was of alcohol, sour, moderate amounts of vinegar with some malt coming through.  Medium body, medium-high carbonation.  Finishes like a fine Flemish Sour.  Its too bad VIctory had a run of bad batches.  Rating 4/4/4/2/8.
Rerate.  Bottle.  Rusty orange in colour.  Aroma was of light alcohol, light citrus, some malt, banana and some wheat.  The flavour was malty, some wheat, caramel, bananas.  Large body, medium carbonation.  Finish is long with a slight tang.  This was truely a different beer then before.

Hazy dark amber with a big tan head.  Aroma is estery and a bit sweet, with typical weizen spiciness.  Alcohol is noticeable up front, but its presence diminishes towards the finish.  Flavor has notes of lemon, pepper, coriander, and some grape.  Not a big fan of wheat beer in general, but this is pretty good.
This big ol wheat beer makes me happy, especially since Im on a wheat kick. Theres a beautifully dark, cloudy pour. Good taste with lots of interesting flavors to pick up.

I beg your pardon? 8.7%? Wow - this is a deliciously drinkable big beer. Gorgeous hazy amber brown body with a thin bubbly off-white head. Spicy and citrusy on the nose, with definite banana and malt. Coats the mouth with a pretty creamy mouthfeel and a wheat and fruit malt flavour. Lingers for a while, nicely.
Interesting Weisse character.  Very sweet malt.  Heavy, but balanced.  Alcohol is exceptionally well hidden.

If youre a fan of Golden Monkey definately treat yourself to this beer. It has a deep caramel coloring that if it was only a little thicker could be drizzled as a dessert topping. It spreads evenly across the palate offering a truly delectable treat.

Pours light hazy amber with a medium sized white head. Aroma is very tart of citrus and berries. Peppery and lots of yeast. Weak banana and caramel. Exepected more.. Finish was a little funky. Solid beer.
Cloudy orange, with a sizey white head. Yeasty, spicy aroma. Spicy and peppery, with notes of coriander and orange. Very slippey palate. Thanks to Doclock for the trade!
Drat at the brewery. Good beer. Nice Weisse aroma and taste. Along with a sweet malt flavor. Very well balanced.

This beer pours an amber/orange color with a thin white head which dissipated rather quickly and left little lacing..very weizenbock typical. Aroma is mild with notes of citrus, peppers, orange peel and malt. Sticky nose...you can almost tell this will have a sticky mouthfeel. Flavor is medium bodied and relativley light in carbonation as to what would have been expected. Grains and wheats are obviously apparent, but so is the slight tinge of alcohol in the finish. Banana, citrus, grape peel and grains are all over this beer, but theres that damn stickyness in the finish. Dry but sticky finish. Tongue-coating maltiness. Interesting fruityness, but overdone syrupy palate and alcohol presence.
Wheat beer is not my thing. But I were to drink a wheat beer this would be it. Kinda reminded me a golden monkey with the spices.
Honey brown in color, with a honey and delicate spice taste. Lightly carbonated with medium head.
Opaque dirty copper-orange with a fizzy head.  Medicinal aroma with a tart orange-alcohol flavor, yet easy to drink.  Nice.

Color is a darker caramel with light white head.  nose is full of light fruits, sugar, some bannana, and yeast.  Taste is simalar but filled with bitterness.  Not bad, but I still like the darker stuff.
Body is a foggy brown, with a bubbly thin head.  Honey, dried fruits, alcohol, grapes, wheat aroma.  Taste is cinnamon, nutmeg, apples, apricots, wheat.  Pretty easy drinking for a 8.7% beer.

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2005 Not cloying in its sweetness as the other few weizen bocks I have tried. The head is large, tan colored and long lasting. Lots of bubbles in the body. The body is amber and slightly cloudy. The aroma is brown sugar, nuts with cherries, bananas and a cinnamon spice. This goes down with a thick mouthfeel. I am going to age a few. This si scary drinkable. Best by March 1, 2005.

bottle thanks to the_beer_god.  pours deep amber.  thin head, but lots of carbonation.  thick sticky wheaty aroma, with some cloves and yeast and banana.  despite the german-ness of the brew, it tastes rather belgian and spicy; acidic and bitter, which fit the style very appropriately.  interesting to say the least!

UPDATED: MAR 2, 2005   This beer had a much lighter pour then I was expecting.  It was an orange color instead of a brown color.  The head was practically non-exisistent.  Very interesting appearance.  The smell was very peppery and spicy.  There was citrus, orange, and caramel in the taste.  The problems were that it was too sweet and too peppery.  The alcohol is also a bit noticable.  Still once again Victory has produced a very good beer.  This is not there best beer in my opinion, but I am still impressed.  The palate has a nice spicyness to it which works quite well.
Orange color, and a thick tan head. Sweet citrus scent, and a nice variety of spices in the flavor. An easy drinking beer, without being too thin.

UPDATED: AUG 11, 2005 Im enjoying this one.  Brown bodied with an off-white head, this baby smells of sweet malts, grassiness, fruity yeasts, and spices.  Caramel and mild citric flavors (mainly orange), pomes, and spices come across in the taste leaving you with a warm banana, spices, and alcohol finish.  A dangerous brew, since I could easily put these away all night long.  The 8.7% abv just hasnt struck me yet.<font size=-4><a href=http://www.ratebeer.com/Places/ShowPlace.asp? Liquors, Chicago, IL<font size=-1>

Bottle. Premier Gourmet in Buffalo. Golden red brown body, fairly clear. Aroma is yeasty, but more of a Belgian like yeastiness than a wheat yeastiness. Sweet malt, touch of caramel, some alcohol as I swirl the glass. Flavour is not what I expected. Lots of sweet malt, some alcohol in the finish with very little wheaty flavours poking through. They start to come out more as it warms, but it is still more bock than weizen. Average medium bodied palate. Nice but unexciting. I had hoped for more.

UPDATED: OCT 12, 2005 Opaque brown body, with a frothy white head that disappears fast.  Aroma is bananas and apples.  Still bananas in the flavor but its followed up with a shot of sweet cherries.  Alcohol very present in the finish.  Great weizenbock.  I had  3 last night while working around the house and started feeling a little numb.

Ruddy orange-red body, thin quickly dissipating off-white head.  Chewy aroma of banana, clove, tangy wheat, and caramel, slightly sharp.  Sweet caramely body, somewhat toasty, with plenty of banana and clove with some development of sweeter fruits (e.g., cherry) from the sugar-charged malts.  Surprisingly strong; alcohol is evident at the finish, after which the banana sticks on the palate for awhile.  This is a very good Weizenbock, and certainly a sipper rather than a session beer!  Thanks Dan (jah noth) for the bottle!

Big banana and clove aroma. Some citric bite coming through too in the flavours. Very rich, with a sweetish finish. A big wheat like this runs the risk of being a bit blowsy and overblown. However, whilst this is undeniably a big, bold, beer it maintains its balance. A classy brew. Bottled at the Green Leafe Cafe, Williamsburg.

Hmm, very...interesting., to say the least.

Pours a cloudy amber with some head and no lacing.

Aroma is of a Belgian Hefe, very fruity; bananas spring to life as does light spices.

Flavor is, well, between a Bock and a Weize: Very fruity with both dark and light fruits. Definate bananas, but apricots, dates, and other fruits play with the tongue. Nicely complex.

Palate is full, to say the least. Its got a nice bite to it. Overall, this is very nice. Its definately worth seeking out!

Aroma is slightly bitter, alchohol, very grainy, and backed with some banana esters. The flavor is strong with alchohol and the grains especially while the yeast comes through in the finish. Only moderately sweet this seems more geared toward the grains than anything else. The alchohol becomes a slight nuisance once it warms a touch but overall the flavor stays strong.

Deep amber and a little hazy but not as hazy as many wheats.  Medium light tan head and decent lacing.  Malty, fruity aroma.  Nice roasted malt flavor with some hops and fruity sweetness of apples and citrus zest.  I thought the mouthfeel was a bit thin but it was a tasty brew all the same.
NIce pour.  Very fruity in flavor.  So much going on in this beer, I cant put it into words...well, that and Im lazy.

Copper in color, aromas of banana immediately present followed by spice.  I always had Aventinus alone at the top, but this one ranks right up there with it.  Nice medium mouthfeel, spices and malt hide the high alcohol exceptionally.  How can this be almost 9%!!  
Super finish as the spice lingers.

Pours a small golden amber hue with a small slight-off-white head with somewhat decent lacing.   Aromas of butter, popcorn, and malt.  Flavor is very very malty and buttery almost like buttered popcorn??? Alcohol is barely noticable with flavors of butter, roasted malts, a little toffee,  banana, a little spice.  Very unique...I havent had any weizenbocks in my time as a an alcoholic, I mean drinker, but this is the most unique lager based brew that I have had.  Fairly bitter finishm yet very addicting.  mmmmm....I kinda like this a lot.
Hazy dark amber color with a small off white head. Aroma of wheat, banana and cloves. Flavor of wheat, cloves, citrus and a quite bitter finish.
Creamy head, light crimson color. Aroma is alcoholic and malty. Taste was totally off. Very sour, no discernable wheat. Very tangy and tart. Im thinking this was a bad bottle.

This is more like Belgian tripel than some Belgian Tripels.Spiced fruit,like those sliced red things they pit on your plate with a hot turkey sandwich.Clove,cinnamon cherries and sweet malt.Flavors arent quite as sharp as I was hoping,I mean if the taste matched the aromas I would have been really impressed.Comes up a little short.

Ruby amber body, slightly cloudy.  Some glowing gold colors.  Head is big, and cherry-vanilla colored.  Smells of wheat , clove and cherry malt.  Taste is sweet and spicy with lots of clove and more cherries and plums. Almost a little too sweet actually. Aftertaste is clove and fruity malt. Nice beer.

Bottle --Mar 10 2005--Thanks willblake!
Pours a cloudy tan/leather color with a decent head that vanishes while your back is turned, leaving just a hint of a foam ring behind.  The nose on this beer may be the most interesting Ive sampled this past year or so--very involved with wheat wang, apples, pears, and maybe clove and nutmeg as well.  The mouthfeel is fuller than I would expect, but I guess for a beer with 8.7% ABV going for it, the mouthfeel is to be expected--its the lighter color that kind of throws me off.

The flavor explodes with all kinds of stuff--banana, pears, nutmeg and clove to be sure, but I get a clear sense of salt water taffy from it.  I also get just a decent level of acidity that helps this beer from being cloyingly sweet, since I dont detect much in the way of hops here.

Truly a flavorful beer, and an interesting experience.  Im not sure that its my everyday cup of tea, but its got the guts to step up and be counted.

Well done!

Of all the phenolic Bavarian wheat syles, weizenbock is the only one I can really get into--and this is no exception. Its a hazy orange-brown with a dissapointing lack of head. The nose is soft with bananas, clove and just a touch of citrus and alcohol. Big fruity wheat body and maybe slightly undercarbonated.   A suprisingly firm dose of bitterness in the finish for the style (though this is hardly a bitter beer by any standard). Very tasty.
Hazy copper color with light head. Nose of wheat & bananas, sweet malts & tasty floral hops. Tastes warm & spicy, lightly bitter with a fruity wheat tail. A bit too bitter but overall fin tasty.

Slightly hazy amber body with abundant carbonation and a fading off-white head. Strong clove-like esters in the aroma plus rich maltiness of caramel and molasses. Also has peppery, yeasty notes. Interesting and unusual rich earthy malt flavor. Includes elements of dark bread crusts, more clove, mild phenols, a hint of chocolate, and yeast. Medium fruity acidity. Significant hop presence. Its all here and I like it.

Orange-copper, with a filmy head and little worm like lace on the glass. Musky aromas. There is a hint of banana and clove. The hops are citrus along the lines of a sweet lemon. Nice caramel malts and some wheat. A touch of alcohol. Flavors contain more malts than the aroma. Caramel mostly. Citrus, grassy and earthy hops. Lemons and oranges. Alcohol comes through. Malty body finishes bitter and wheaty.

Very good. I didnt know what to expect with this one but I have to say that I am pleasantly surprised. Cloudy reddish-brown appearance, fruity, sweet aroma and flavor along the lines of a Belgian brew.

Pours orangeish-amber with a generous head. Fruity and yeasty aroma of a wheat beer. Nice flavor--you can pick out both the wheat beer and the bock. Slightly spicy finish, almost like a tripel. Decent stuff.

Victory makes some great stuff.  Among my favorites of many styles you will find one from Victory.  This is a good one but not exceptional.  Hazy orange/amber with a quickly gone head.  Fruity aroma: banana, pear, whatever.  Maybe baked banana bread.  Spicy.  Medium body and slightly thin texture.  Good carbonation.  Flavor was appealing.  Notes of that banana bread, malt.  Okay, I liked it.

Bottle:  Lasting beige head on a medium amber cloudy body.  Clove yeast, banana, plum fruit, and floral hop in the initial aroma.  grainy wheat malt & a little caramel and bready malt follows.  Well balanced w/ wheat malt up front in the flavor, some clove and earthy hop flavors in the finish.  Malt is also toasty, but it seems to be missing the banana in the flavor.  Medium body, higher carbonation, well hidden alcohol; smooth.  A decent WB, but not outstanding.

A nice aroma with some clove notes and alot of fruit an almost plum nose. the body was rich and full to style the alochol was hidden and smooth. although not an Aventinus this does qualify for a little brother. I was impressed but I need more alot more in weisenbock.

brown and cloudy with a little tan head.  Has a barley wine type aroma full of frits and alcohol.  The taste is very much full of fruits, and is also farily sour.  There is a malt base that builds but stays mostly out of the way and also a mostly hidden bitterness.  It has an aquward finish, sour and slightly vineous.

Has a yeasty banana caramely nose  and a cloudy dark burnt orange appearnace.  It had a good head  that dispersed quickly. Nice caamel and banana flavor. Can taste some alcohol, nice warmming quality.  Medium to full bodied with  a creamy texture. Good weizenbock a tasy brew on cold winter nights.

Pours a dark redorange, with small white head. Aroma is bananas, lemon, and peaches.  Flavor is malty and smooth, lemons and cloves come in, as do other fruits, and basil? sage? cant quite pick out which herb im smelling. A little thin on the palate, but a great brew! Thanks to GoldTwins for this tasty one!

Dark brandy-colored body.  The aroma has the expected big malts - dark wheat bread, prunes, and maybe a little smokiness.  The flavor is much "brighter" due to a big citrus taste in the start.  The same dark malty elements in the aroma make a second appearance at the end of the flavor.  Dry, hoppy finish with cherry sweetness.  A little rough around the edges, the dry finish doesnt sit well with the rest of the sweet flavor but otherwise a fine beer.

Pours a dark cloudy amber with a quickly fading head. Aroma is spicy with cloves. Taste has strong notes of caramel, citrus and dark fruits, wheat along with belgian brew spices and yeast. Pretty complex, VERY sweet, not much bitterness. Alcohol content very well hidden. Mouthfeel is full and round. Quality brew, but its not really my thing.

Poured a very murky light brown with a white head that dissipated completely.  Aroma is very spicy with subtle fruit traces.  Taste is not as sweet as I expected.  The predominant flavor is spice, with some fruit tones and an alcoholic twinge to the finish.  Not bad, but not as drinkable as some other weizen bocks Ive had.

Copper amber color, hazy, with a slightly off-white head. Aroma is full of fruit, a little bit yeasty and spicy as well. Nice sweet and sour flavor, with once again a lot of fruits (banana, orange, apple) and spices (cloves rule). Sour taste turns into tart aftertaste. Pretty nice mouthfeel despite an overall medium-bodied beer.
