UPDATED: NOV 10, 2004 man does this beer come back on you the next day and make its presence known, shall we say, in an unpleasant olifactory manner.  but, the beer itself is nice.  lackluster head retention, good banana esters from the yeast, full body, sneaky alcohol strength.  good, but the more i drink it, the less i find myself enjoying it.  good for a couple pints, then diminishing returns.

Hazy amber with high carbonation but a little diminishing head. Aroma is similar to one of a wheat beer. The flavor is similar to a wheat with some Belgian-type flavor and banana mixed in. Alcohol is noticeable.

UPDATED: JAN 4, 2005 Hazy amber accompanied by a huge head.
The aroma was sour and yeasty.
The flavor was malty with a very crisp acid bite that wasnt quite right.
Maybe this was a bad bottle?? Too much wheat tang sourness and not enough Bock maltiness. Ill have to try this again.
Re-rate Current Numbers reflect the re-rate. The first one was a bad bottle.
Same appearance as above.
Aroma is citrus, yeast and malt, somewhat between a Belgian Golden Ale and a Bock. 
Sweet, with a bit of tartness at the finish.
Much better and glad I tried it again.
lots of banana. great bock that sneaks up on you. great fall color. bitter, until you get over the shock.
Cloudy amber color with asmall off-white head. Banana, clove and malt aroma. Very sweet clove, banana bread and malt flavors. Medium feel with a lightly dry finish.

Cloudy deep orange/brown color with a small beige head. The aroma was full of bananas, clove, yeast/bread, and sugar. The flavor was quite sweet with bananas, cloves, and yeast. The feel was kinda on the thin side for me...acidic/dry finish. Very good weizen Bock. Thanks for the surprise Willblake!

Cloudy dark brown color.  Jine doesn?t lie. This a good weizenbock.  Alcohol is very evident.  Sweet and delicious.  Slightly acidic.   Not an Aventinus, but another good beer from Victory.  Beautiful bottle as well.
Bottle.  Yum Weizen Bocks Yum.  Youll like this, I swear.  Dont doubt, I wouldnt lie to you about this.
nice orange amber color, thick carbonated head.  Fairly hoppy throughout, awesome sweet spicy taste and thick wheaty malts.  Id say, an excellent Weizen Bock.

Bright, cloudy reddish-amber. Good carbonation. Large light tan head.  Aroma of banana, biscuit, caramel, & vanilla w/ some light peppery notes. Light, mildly acidic feel. Fruity flavour of banana & apple w/ soft, rounded malt (biscuit, caramel, toffee) in the background. Finish is long & warm w/ peppery notes.
Nice dark red pour. Good faomy/lace head. Nice spicy aroma, sugar-cinnamin. I like bocks and this just gets better as I drink more. There is plenty of alcohol and I like this.

This brew pours a hazy orange/copper with a white head that leaves moderate lacing on the glass. Lots of wheat and spice in the aroma, fruity with a light floral hopping, and a faint banana smell. This brew has a very amazing well-rounded taste with a nice wheaty/yeasty start and a faint sweetness. This brew finishes with a crisp spicy balanced finish, slightly fruity, with just a faint bitterness to balance out the taste. Very smooth for a 8.7% weizen.

Bottle pours a cloudy caramel, medium off-white pancake batter like head, subtle carbonation, with fairly attractive lacing. &nbsp Banana & cloves on the nose. &nbsp Tiz also rather bready with its wheat malts. &nbsp Quite bready and wheaty on the tongue, with spices and a touch of alcohol. &nbsp Fairly tasty, almost like a slimmed down version of Schneiders. &nbsp Medium body & mouthfeel. &nbsp Finishes with more alcohol than I prefer, but with a nice spiced bready flavor.

Poured ruby and cloudy with a thin tan head...smelled fruity and alcohol...pears and oranges and allspice...thin mouthfeel...tasted melons and molasses and caramel...quick alcohol finish...surprised by 8.7%...wouldnt have guessed it that high due to its drinkability...

Bottle:  Hazy ruby/light brown color with a very small white head that diminishes to the outside of the glass, then quickly disappears.  Aroma is sweet, filled with bananas, banana peel, peach, clove, apple, wheat and yeast.  Initially this beer tastes good, but not like anything special.  Though the more I drink, the more I am impressed.  Flavor has lots of ripe banana, peach, wheat, slightly spicey yeast, cinnamon sugar, orange, with just a bit of bitterness and lemon somewhere.  Finishes surprisingly crisp and dry, with a clean mouthfeel.
Big aroma, big ABV, BIG flavor, Big score.  This beer has a shockingly full and rich flavor, laden with fruits and the familiar taste of a Victory brew.  A pleasure from start to finish.

cloudy brownish color, light brown head, sticks around an average length.  smells deep and alcoholic but does not taste it.  carbonation couples with the biterness for an interesting flavor.  just like having a good weizen bock in germany.
On tap at the 2004 Kennett Square BF. Poured a hazy, medium orange color with a off white head. Sweet and spicy. Bananas as well. Not bad.

The initial taste that is experienced is so unique and invigorating.  I believe I had this from the tap at Victory, and do not remember it being so great.  The aroma, apperance, and flavor are all excellent.  I thought that over time, I would get tired of the flavor, but to the last sip it was truly sublime.  Again, there are not enough superlatives to describe the quality of Victory brews.

Small head quickly diminishes.  Cloudy brownish orange color.  Aroma is sweet smelling of bananas, peach, clove and alcohol.  Flavor is mostly bananas with a light lemon at the finish.  Alcohol taste is noticable but not overwhelming.  Warming in  the throat.  Medium body.

UPDATED: OCT 10, 2004 Redish amber color. Aromas of spice, wheat and banana. Flavors are sweet malt, bananas, spice, caramel and hops.
Body is medium, and just right. This is very good...it caught me by surprise.
Update - I tried another one, one day later...even better.

10.06.04  12oz bottle.  Pours a clouded, fiery reddish amber with a wispy tan head.  Aroma is spicey banana and creamy, smells like autumn.  Body is fuller than I expected, although I admittedly did not know what to expect.  The beer reminds me little of Aventinus, but may be just as good...or better.  Alcohol emerges and warms with temp.  This is like bananas and milk and cinnamon sugar and some orange candy, all with notes of musty pumpkin.  And it tastes really good.

UPDATED: DEC 7, 2008 [12 oz. bottle] Cloudy amber color with a quickly falling off-white head. Very fruity and spicy aroma with hints of yeast and wheat. Taste is very complex. Mixtures of wheat, yeast, clove, banana and a very slight hop note at the end. Nice sweet and lingering aftertaste. Very tasty.

Received a bottle from Slob. Color is cloudy amber (much lighter and cloudier than Aventinus). Aroma is fruity and spicy but not much clove or banana. More cherry-like. Taste is wonderfully interesting. Lots of banana and clove here. The wheat chatacter is also evident. Finishes sweet with a lingering alcohol bite. Great beer.

Tap @ Victory. Cloudy amber/brn w good lt. beige head that fell quick. Nose was rich malt w a touch of clove & very light hops. Flavor was quite clovey, slightly sweet w min hops. The full clove effect doesnt go well with me yet, or maybe never.

The pour is a light mahogany. Nice color, rather dark. The head is thin, dense and mostly diminishing. 

The nose is a silent killer. It is truly phenomenal. Tart cherries, apple skin and suprisingly there are not many traditional weizen flavors (babana, nutmeg and clove), some but very little. The smell is lovely but bizarre for the style. It sort of resembles a brown beer from flanders in its nose. 

The first taste is luscious, sharp and full of flavor. Banana first, then a clove spicyness along with a little peach. Next is the sourness. Its bizarre but acidic and full of a lovely sour apple and orange spicyness. The alcohol is hidden throughout, until the finish where it aids in a delicious aftertaste. The wheat and the yeast play a backup roll but they both perform to the best of their abilities. Very clean. 

Wow, another stunning Victory. A great interpretation of the style. Everything I was looking for.
Rich copper color.  Aroma is wheaty lemon,  a bit of sweet malt, some hints of dark fruit.  This is an odd combination of flavors.  Sweet and wheaty, slightly alcoholic, yeasty with a bit of lemon.

UPDATED: JAN 9, 2007 Pour is a copper red with a small creamy head.  Malty spicy aroma with that standard weizen smell.  Pretty damn good in this mans humble opinion. Weizenbocks are far from my standard lineup, so it was nice to have something different. 7/3/6/3/15. 
RERATE: 2006 Version. Dark muddy brown color with a thin white creamy head of tiny bubbles.  Aroma is sweet and malty with a touch of something citric.  Flavor is smooth, well blended smokey sweetness and that raspy wheat finish. Just a hint of citrus hidden somewhere.  Pretty tasty.
12 oz botte. Cloudy brownish and yellow in color with a whitesh head. Malty banana flavor. Banana nose. Drinkable. Smooth palate.
12 oz bottle. Cloudy brownish yellow, whitish head. Banana-malt-alcohol nose. Malty banana flavor. Smooth palate. A little heat. Maybe a touch of vanilla.
user_location: Good Beer Bar Deprived, New Jersey, USA

text:
12 oz. brown, longneck bottle. One of a six-pack. Freshness date is of Mar 01 05. Loud pfftt when opened. Poured out a hazy, orangish caramel color, with a huge tan head at first. It slid back to a thin lacing on top of the beer itself. Aromas are of orange caramel cremes, cloves, slight bubblegum, not too much in the way of banana, yeasty bread, and fresh malts. Tastes are of oranges, caramel cremes, cloves, malts, vanilla, and the flavors change as the beer warms up. Thick, rich mouthfeel, creamy and smooth. Alcohol hits you as its swallowed, warming you right up.
Finishes somewhat fruity, and alcoholic. A really well made Weizenbock.

UPDATED: OCT 13, 2004 Ruby red, fizzy off-white head. Has a spicy and fruity (apples, cherries, blueberry, lemon) barleywine-like aroma with a minimal amount of hops and a touch of yeast. Taste has a sour aspect to it.... a little tart with citrusy cherry, some slight woody hops and topped with wheat. Full bodied, and a little thick.

Definitely a great seasonal bock that is great for any occasion.  The spicyness of the beer makes me long for cool fall nights and trick or treaters.  Not much aroma to this beer but the taste is exceptional and not what I expected.  This beer is definitely worth a try.

This was a fantastic beer.  It poured a nice cloudy reddish brown with a very bubbly head.  The aroma was a variety of fruitiness and spiciness, and the taste was very similar.  This is a great beer to relax with in the late summer or early fall and one that I highly recommend.

Fresh 04 bottle.  Deep ultra hazy browns and oranges, creamy khaki colored head.  The nose is filled with spicy clove, banana, pear, caramel, and yeasty bread dough.  The flavor is similar with notes of spiced fruit,  malt, and only a a slight hint of hops at the very end.  Medium to full bodied, fizzy carbonation, smooth, spicy, fruity finish.  This beer is perfect for those crisp cool Autumn nights....

Tap @ Blind Tiger. Something about Victory beers Im not liking much anymore. The alcohol taste is the first thing I notice. There doesnt seem to be too much balance, as the malt is all over the place. Small head. Alcohol aroma. Lightly sour.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2004 Draught @ Victory:  This one is a rich, cloudy orangish-brown color.  There was no head on my sample.  The aroma was highlighted by notes of banana and clove, as well as some dark fruits and caramel.  The taste was a rich malty sweet, but not overly so.  Some Yeatiness, as well as hints of the banana,dark fruits and clove also.  Another very good one!  Even my mother and wife liked this one!

Got it for free on tap at Victory.....dont ask how....Anyway it poured out a nice reddish amber color with a medium sized, light head. It has a fruity taste with notes of malt and a somewhat bitter finish. I usually dont like wheat beers that much, but this is the first of this style Ive had, and what can I say...its good stuff, nothing short of my expectations from Victory.
UPDATED: AUG 30, 2004 It has an amroma of a big Belgian Ale, quite fuity.  Taste is also like a belgian ale, stong, fuity, with a yeaty taste.  This is good.  As most Victory beers are!

bottled, sweet stewed pear waftage, immediately went flat in the glass, light browny purple. a little too sweet for my tastes, becomes cloying, some icing sugar. doesn´t taste much of alcohol but quite warming in the gut. i just couldn´t get excited about it

UPDATED: FEB 12, 2007 Dark ruby color - thin head.  Some caramel malts with a sour wheat-ish finish and a bit of spice.  Gets better as it warms.  Not one of their better beers though.

RERATE: 2/12/07 - Hits me a lot better than before - has a nice hint of fruit (cherries, maybe a bit of lemon), some caramel sweetness.

Nice, dense, light tan head of fine bubbles.  Creamy in top.  Soft aroma with bread, pears and a good helping of malt.  Color is a slightly cloudy brown/mahagony.  Sour flavor but not overpowering.  Fruity, with very little wheat present.  Finish is tart and leaves a thin puckering film in the mouth.  Not exactly what I expected but a decent beer none-the-less.
Attractive red amber.No head. Flemmish style sour aroma. Flavour starts strong with a slight sour edge.

Malty aroma, sourness, fruits, bubblegum. Pours a cloudy orange-brown, off-tan head. Satisfying sweetness, chocolate undertones, tartness in the finish. Mouthfeel is enjoyable despite low malt. An excellent weizenbock.
Bottle:  Pours turbid diarrhea colored.  Aroma of fruit and spiciness.  Tastes of yeast and acidic esters.  Sour finish with some citrus and fruit.  Nice beer.

Sour, yeasty Flemish sour-like aroma. Cloudy, light brown colour with decent tan head that recedes to ring. Sour, lightly acetic malty flavour with nice roasty charcoal finish. Body is fairly light but mouthfeel is quite full perhaps due to carbonation. Enjoyed with MartinT and Rastacouere. Bottle.
Brownish-red color, has a semi-sweet fruit undertone with rum, raisin, and light caramel. Medium-light bodied.

Pour is a rather ugly color, a dark, translucent brown with a significant creamy, beige head.  Aroma is yeast, citrus, raisin.  Flavor is quite sour with lots of citrus (acidity) and dark fruits.  The first sip is just an explosion of fruitiness.  Finish extremely sour with virtually no bitterness.  Really unique, and very tasty.  Above-average richness.  Im really surprised at how many people (especially high-ratings-count people) have given this drink absolutely horrible ratings.  I am really impressed by this; its one of the more unique beers I have tried, and I really like it.  The first ounce is better than the last, though; I think the sourness starts to overpower the fruit as you get through the beer.  Oh, and I wouldnt have suspected this was anywhere even close to 8.7% alcohol.  Nice stuff.

Appearance: a hazy, rich autumnal crimson color, and a nice, toasted, creamy head.
Aroma: mmmm, nice, deep and delirious, fruity, spicy, wide open and delicious, instantly reminding me of Aventinus. That's always a nice thing.
Taste: plenty of it! Tantalizing, mouthfilling, happily coating the palate, leaving behind spicy, grapey flavors. A bit light going down, but never lagging with the flavor. Medium bodied, nicely textured...they'd have to go a little further with it to make it outstanding, but this is a tasty treat and a nice stab at the style.

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2011  I really liked this beer for taste reasons that I find hard to put into words.+++Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer pours a nut brown color with a small tan head. There is a sour aroma with some wheat noticeable but it was a bit muddled.  The flavor is sour, malty, and fruity with a light vinegar bitterness on the finish. Very Belgian in character. Interesting.

Pours a deep amber with a big brown head. Aromas of raisins, dried figs, cloves, and bananas. Sweet on the front of the tongue with a very mild but noticeable bitterness on the back. Alocoholic as it warms but a bit sour. Maybe the temp. was not consistent as it aged.

Poured a deep amber with a thin tan head.

Aroma is super sweet but a light sweetness, think pixy stix sweet. 

Taste is sweet rich malt balanced by sourness and fruit flavors. Very, very tasty.

A very different beer all around. At first glance, taste doesn't match appearance, but upon further inspection it does. The color suggests sweet bock but the hazy yeastiness suggests fruit and spice, in the end all are present.

Bottle says "Enjoy by Aug 20 04". I did anything but "Enjoy" this one. The taste of this beer is outright not at all what I was expecting it to be for a weizen bock of which I have rated six total. It had a medium sized creamy and smooth vanilla head with fine sized bubbles. The body was carbonated and semi-transparent with an orange-brown hue. The nose was fruity, spicy and citrus. The flavor was acidic, lightly bitter, very sour tasting, and somewhat exotic fruity tasting which did not set well with my palate by any means. A disappointment from Victory in my opinion.

This bottled brew labeled August 20, 2004 poured a large sized head of fine to large sized light brown colored long lasting bubbles that left behind a fair lacing.  The body was a semi-transparent brown color with no visible carbonation.  The aroma was mix of brown beer, floral, fruit and malt.  Interesting to say the least.  The mouth feel is sour and off with an initial repulsive reaction from me.  Not what I was expecting at all.  The flavor contains notes of clove, mild vinuousness, malt,  fruity esters and probably a few others that are quite exotic.  A strange brew that did not fit my palate at all.
This is a fine beer. Nice fruity aroma with bananas and cloves. Hazy red brown in colour. Thinish but pleasant notes of bananas and cloves come out to make the palate happy.

Deep red brown color, with a nice thick cream head.  Aroma is top notch in complexity.  Has sweeter notes of grape, banana and plum, yet balances it out with the wheat, some spice, like nutmeg and clove.  Taste hides the alcohol quite well, as it is smooth intially then has a considerable bite to the end of it.  Leaves a warm sweeter feel on the tongue and a little sizzle on the lips.  One of the best beers I've had in a while, but what else would I expect from victory.
Taste is very sweet, yeasty, and sour (bananas, apples, plums, raisins).  Nice mixture between the bock and the wheat.  Not for me though.

Aroma is wheat, grapes, lemons, bananas and caramel. Apperance is a murky brown with a moderate off white head and fair lacing. Flavor is syrupy with a very strong grape presence. A good kick of sour fruit, banana, wheat, and tart apples. The finish is thick on the tounge with a moderate alcohol burn. A nice beer and something to be sipped on slowly. I've heard of an infection problem on the best by 8/20/04 bottles but my bottle seems fine. And if its a bacteria causing the pleasent sourness, then rock on bottle infection! Once again I thank cb and TAR for providing this beer.

12 oz bottle.  Bready, yeasty, lemony in the nose -- is this a "weizengueuzebock"?  Infected perhaps -- not very bock-like at all, though the bottle didn't gush as infected beers are wont to do.  Very acidic and carbonated, little in the way of "bock" or wheat profile, more citrusy than caramelly or woody/smoky.  Still, infected or not, off-style or not, it's tasty and worth a try.  I hope to have it again and find out if this bottle was a sport.

UPDATED: MAY 22, 2004 Citric aroma bouncing off wheaty yeast...Chocolate earth underneath the lemony profile...If Schoune had a weizenbock, this would be it...Is this a tasty infection or just how it is supposed to be?...

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2004 This beer pours a brown body with low apparent carbonation and a very quickly diminishing off-white head. Aroma is of banana, brown sugar and citric notes (grapefruity). Not too complex and no Aventinus. Taste has a light sourness from the wheat and more banana/brown sugar flavours. Body is thin-medium. I don't think this was infected, but still it had a sourness that seems out of order in this style. Luckily I've got another bottle and a re-rate is in order. Thanks Mike!

The_Beer_God with the hook up on the MoonGlow, I let this baby sit for a few months so I think it’s about ripe,  ~ Thanks Mike!
 Pours a mahogany body with a THICK and frothy kaki head. Nice malty fruity aroma, nose of apples, peaches, apricots, plums, tangerine, and a dry yeastiness. Lets take a sip….. kind of a sour shock that I was not expecting! I certainly picks up some sweet toffee / caramel notes in the finish but he initial punch has a bitter doughy rotten lemon bite, very strange. It’s like an old bruised pear with some coriander, clove and nutmeg sprinkled atop. But the finish fades to a herbal spicy honey resemblance… I don’t know what’s going on with this brew? I’m on the fence with this one……. I wish I could show this brew more love but it’s just kind like an armpit with honey and spice.
Deep amber,cloudy in color with a small white head.Sweet banana bread-like flavor and aroma.A very nice wheat tang and subtle spiciness.

nice rusty brown/auburn body.  foamy tan head.  cloudy and full.  estery and spicy with nice wheat background.  some subdued ripe fruity notes as well.  Very full, creamy mouthfeel.  Ripe, dry and real warm.  Spicy and sweet.  a good bock, a decent wheat profile.

Thanks to The_Beer_God for this one.  It pours an amber/brown, super hazy, with a quickly dissipating, fizzy tan head.  Aroma very yeasty and spicy, with the usual banana and clove notes.  Flavor is tart, acidic, and dry with a lingering sweetness.  Very wheaty as well.  The 8.7% is not noticeable at all.
Amber in color, nice off-white head, lots of spices all over the place in this beer, banana & clove in the nose as well as in the flavors, a bit of a yeasty finish with more banana
Dark caramel color with a large sand colored head.  Strong wheat characteristics in aroma, yeast, banana, cloves.  A sweet tasting bread with the alcohol not noticable.  Very good.

Medium brown with a huge beige head that faded fast and left no lace. Apples , bananas, clove and cinnamon.
Not what I expected, but tasty nonetheless
(Bottle)  Pours a cooper-brown color with a medium beige head.  Has multiple fruit flavors of banana, apple, and lemon, as well as some spicy flavor.

Brown, little head, cloudy with yeast. Strong banana nose. Medium sweet with banana wheat tanginess. (I'd probably be more impressed with this beer if it didn't taste shockingly like my second batch of homebrew, which was the result of accidentally adding 20% too much malt to the brew kettle!).

Spicy, estery aroma, definite banana and clove, some bready, malty, caramel sweetness, cookie dough, also just a bit of sour, rotting fruit, and perhaps a tad of mustiness.  Light reddish-brown color, hazy and sedimented, with a lasting, creamy, ivory head.  Flavor is a mixture of sweet, grainy caramel maltiness, citrusy lemon, mushy old brown banana, apple juice, spices, yeast and peppery alcohol in the finish along with a faint amount of hop bitterness.  Rather unwelcome fizzy palate, medium-full body.  Suffering from a sour infection and a lack of integration.  Finishable but not good.  It can't be meant to taste like this, but this is apparently a widespread problem with this and other Victory beers.  Quality Control dept. not exactly earning their keep over there, methinks.

Pour is a cloudy mahogany, medium sized tan head that mostly diminishes and leaves small bits of lace.  Aroma is strong on the banana, some grain (think banana bread), and some sugary sweetness.  Flavor is sweet, fruity (banana, apple, pear), and ends with some spiciness.  Fairly full bodied, slightly acidic.
UPDATED: DEC 24, 2003 Bottle.  Not much carbonation and no head, disappointing for a wheat beer. Lemony zest doesn't do it for me.  This gets worse with each sampling
I thought of a good cooking apple that was somewhat sweet, with some sourness, but not overly acidic.  Very rich Ruby color.

The aroma is nice and somewhat unexpected. It's sweet, flowery, and very nice with a hint of sourness. The appearance is great - dark brown. The flavor is not what I expected. Good up front with a wheaty flavor followed by a sour finish. The mouthfeel is thick but not detrimentally so in this case. I like the overall affect but I feel I don't know enough about the Weizen Bock style to give this a truly accurate rating.

UPDATED: DEC 3, 2003 A sour, stinging and rotten-food aroma is eminating out of my weizen glass... it looks great... has a nice soft and dark brown appearance, and the aroma is close to being good.. has a wheaty, sweet apple juice and spice aroma, but there is a metallic-chemical smell in there as well, and it's also there in the flavor.  Gooey and sticky mouthfeel make it feel like carbonated, flavored IHOP syrup, and it is entirely too sour, almost undrinkable, but there are some positive qualities in the nice citrus flavors... puckering like some American wheats were before the big change.  Thanks to Eric for this one!

UPDATED: DEC 1, 2003 Drinkable, but sour.  Cloudy yellow looks like a classic weizen bock, but over run with infection I believe.  Sour is not a flavor I'd expect for a Weisen Bock, but this was a least drinkable.  V10 wasn't.

(Bottle) Pours a thin, beige, frothy head and a cloudy, reddish body. Nose of sweet, bruised bananas, yeast, tartness and slight caramel. Awfully sour notes though the banana comes through. Great texture, beautiful body - so sad about the infection. As noted in the RB forum, Victory is suffering serious contamination problems for their best before date batch of August 20, 2004. So sad this will likely be my only opportunity to sample this beer...

UPDATED: OCT 18, 2004 2003 draught. Muddy caramel brown, with some dark browns, tans and lighter brownish yellows.  Very cloudy, big medium brown light coffee colored head.  Light wheat aroma, some alcohol, definitely peaches and mabye some brown sugar or caramel malt.  Begins with a big dose of malty sweetness, which is accented even further by a rich peachy flavor.  Wonderful chewy/grainy texture that provides a full body. Tons of wheat in here.  Lighter, sharper hops come out in the finish; apricots sugar and finally some nice yeasty flavor.  Big alcohol notes, (but not too big).  Bananas and more sweetness linger on the palate after the finish.  Very impressive, though could definitely stand to tone down the sweetness.

Super nice concentrated color, looks like a solid glass of dark caramel, some yellowness peaks around the edges, a thin loose tannish head emerged that didn't last and the lacing is very minimal. Aroma is super tangy of fruity citrus, ripe melon, orange peels, mango, peach, dulled grapes, quite a fruit juice effect in the aroma, underlaying sweet malts and musty yeast, notes of ethanol. Taste is a lip smacking attack of tangy dullish citrusy fruits, mostly orange peels and peach skins with some mango and light banana mixed in. Pretty sweet and quickly tangy, malty, twingy with notes of raw orange peels coming through late in the finish as it drys out somewhat and keeping a sweetly souring, almost puckering tang. Feel is a bit thin at first but begins to fill in as it goes and drys out some in the finish. Sneaky alcohol hits your head after half the glass. A pretty decent brew, the tangyness is pretty high with a overall orange peel effect throughout its character. I can see where some would like this, but I don't think I'd try this again, but I wouldn't turn it down if offered either. I'm kinda torn with this one, I want to like it cuz Victory makes some fantastic brews, but something with this beer keeps me from thoroughly enjoying it.

Yeasty aroma with banana esters.  Cloudy, dark amber appearance.  Tart taste leaned toward a spicy, fruity flavor with a moderate amount of malt sweetness.  Deceptive alcohol content.  Light acidic finish.

Pretty hazy amber appearance, nice head.  Huge bursting aroma of clove, banana, juicy fruit gum.  An almost oily mouthfeel.  Flavor was sweet, really a bit cloying.  Some citric tartness tried to break through, but was ultimately unsuccessful.  Clove and berry flavors throughout.  Just couldn't get past the sweetness, a typical problem I have with this style.

Very big yeasty, candy corn aroma with hints of spice and bannana. Drak orange color with small head and light lace. Flavor starts sour and appley(pear perhaps), then the yeast and malt shine through a little more. Finishes tart and tangy. Slight alcohol presence notcieable throughout. Spicieness comes through as it warms as do hints of bannana

UPDATED: NOV 24, 2003 Bottle-dark mahogony appearance-very cloudy.  candy coated aroma between a tripple and a dopplebock.  super complex palate-sweet and sour.  aggressive needle feeling on the toungue.  pretty sour.  sugary finish, which was pretty good.  I wonder what aging this brew would do to the flavor profile?  thanks to Bunkypop for hooking me up with a suprise from my want list!

Sweet banana aroma.  Gorgeous cloudy, rich amber appearace.  Nice malt flavor with a hint of cinnamon  The citric juices are also delectable.  Finish is crisp with a sour lime taste.  Very nice indeed.

Dear Gawd!  It's got way too much sour in it.  I'm starting to think this beer skunks easily or something because many of the ratings reflect a similar off taste I found here.  Not one of the best Victorys by any means.

Started off odd - aroma seemed off - some herbal/clove, but also a tiny bit "acidy".  Sweet banana cinnamon bread maltyness, but too fizzy.  Gained sour acid qualities as I drained the bottle.  Mine was also "best by 8/20/04" - not a good sign.

Cloudy amber body, thin head. Fruity aroma of bananas and pears. Spicy fruit malt with lots of banana and pear, lightly carmelly and wheaty. Finish is a little too acidic for me, but alcohol content seems not present. A good autumn brew but not one of my favorites from this outstanding brewery.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2004 Enjoy by Mar 01 05.  This bottle is so much better than the last one.  Color is same, with whispy off-white head.  Nose of clove, banana and Kraft caramels.  Syrupy mouthfeel with a noticable amount of alcohol.  Lots of caramel sweetness, spicey bight, and well balanced citrus hops in the finish.  Like a huge German Wheat.  This is what I expected the first time.  Very tastey beer.

Murky, almost transluscent orange color with hot-chocolate looking head.  I also had the "enjoy by 8-20-04" bottle, and it did taste like it was starting to go.  The initial taste was strong banana clove with a nice wheat mouthfeel, but then it got very acidic with a funky sourness to it.  It seemed like a once good beer that may have sat in the sun too long.  I almost didnt rate it, but with almost a year left on the date, be forwarned if you see it.  Id like to try another batch.

UPDATED: DEC 28, 2003 foggy, huh? wheat, citrus aroma. citrus lemon orange, banana. leathery. a very high  acidic orange/citrus taste. feels good.
better aftertaste than initial taste, probably because of the acidity. wait a minute... bad bad sourness. sour done bad. there's a problem here, it cannot be the brewer's intention. i have to re-rate.

Bottle is "enjoy by Aug/04". Head is initially average sized, frothy, light brown, mostly diminishing. Body is murky medium brown. Aroma is moderately malty (bread, caramel), lightly yeasty (cobwebs), with notes of banana, toffee. Flavor is moderately sweet, moderately acidic, acetic. Finish is lightly sweet, heavily acidic, lightly bitter, acetic. Medium body, watery texture, lively carbonation. The sourness is off here, like orange juice that has begun to turn...infected, perhaps.  Nice enough aroma, but nearly undrinkable.
Poured a cloudy brown color with no head or lacing.  Mild citrusy, clove aroma.  Sticky sweet taste of citrus fruits, in particular harvest fruit, as noted in the commercial description.
Aroma is banana, clove, yeasty-typical weizen beer.  A little bit of alcohol.  Low carbonation with a sweet flavor. A tinge of fruit and spice.  Tasty.

Thanks to Pabobcat for the brew. Neat multicolored hue that is orange on the outside and brown in the middle. Good off-white head and very good lace. Aroma is very weizen: lemony, banana, spices, wheat, and yeast with a toasted malt nose amplified by the bock nature of the brew. Yummy fruity and spicy taste initially followed by a mild bitter and zesty yeast character. Lively and smooth mouthfeel with a lingering spice finish. Alcohol was completely masked, great job. Well done and very enjoyable beer. Citrusy enough to be refreshing yet increased body to be a fall classic. I liked it a lot and will need to get more.

Great ruby tinted dark copper colour with a thick, dense tan head that leaves a perfect lacing behind. Great aroma consisting of yeast, wheat, caramel sweetness, bananas and even a hint of grapes. Medium-bodied; Strong maltiness masked with the banana flavour as well as some spices (think cloves, even allspice). Aftertaste is a bit thin, but still leaves behind a great spiceyness with the adequate amount of sweetness. Overall, a great beer, definately one to be had by everyone! I bought this twelve ounce bottle (Best by 11-September-2004) at Beers of the World in Rochester, New York.

yeasty aroma with slight lemon and banana esthers, cloudy reddish orange appearance is a perfect synergy between bock and weizen, soft mouthfeel with bock sweetness and hints of lemon with a bitter finish

wow...dont think i've ever gotten as big a banana aroma from anything other than an actual banana. some citrus present in the aroma as well with maybe a little clove, but the spices are mostly masked to this nose. big banana flavor and large amounts of citrus (orange), but not bitter at all...alcohol is 100% masked. this is one of the strangest beers i've tasted, but damned good.

Dark amber with a tan head. Nice aromatic beer - banana, clove, and spice.  Tastes of banana, yeast, spice, and malt.  Sweet fruity aftertaste.  Higher alcohol content not noticeable in the flavor.  Excellent!
Hazy reddish brown, tan head, banana, clove and a hint of alcohol in the nose. Tart start, banana middle, slightly bitter finish. Minimal alcohol presence on the palate is a plus.
Nice burnt caramel color with off-white head. First sniff is fruit and wheat. Initial taste is sweet bananas. Chewy mouthfeel. Really like this lager.

A lovely dark amber color and impressive light tan head start off this one from Victory.  Nose is wheaty, with some very nice fruit (banana?) notes.  Banana is even more noticable on initial tasting.  Good full flavor, dominated much more by the fruits than the wheat, but perhaps a little too much of the banana is present here.  Also, there is an interesting aftertaste I can't place my finger on, and that just doesn't sit too well with me.  Not a bad beer, by any stretch of the imagination, but not my cup of tea, either.

Cloudy reddish-brown color with a small off-white head that quickly disappears, no lacing. Fruity and spicy aromas of bananas, cloves and vanilla. Wheat flavor with sour apples, vanilla and bubblegum. Full bodied with a full and thick mouthfeel, perfect carbonation, finishes sweet and sour. Alcohol very well hidden, very nice.
Deep ruby/brown color, hazy, with a tan head. Yeasty and fruity aroma. The full flavor was of fruit, yeast, malt, and spice. Nice body. Some warming. Yummy.

UPDATED: JAN 6, 2004 Very tasty,yeasty,dark,
bananna-malt,hops,smooth,decen bananna coloured head,nice lace(in goblet)There is a nice citric appeal that lingers ever so slightly in the finish(dry)I love you Victory(Bill&Ron&staff)Just to let you guys know this was from the best before 9/11/04.The whole infection thing is sad considering they sent the best before 9-11 batch first then the sour BB 8-20 batch shame on you victory.I never did have a bunk one and feel like victory owes their consumers some hop wollop refunds for this mishap?
It's hard to put down this excellent bock beer.   Moderate yeasty aroma, dark amber color with a doughy-yeasty, smokey flavor.   A fresh draft of Moonglow is a rare treat, and worth seeking out.
Another classic from Victory.  Clove, alcohol aroma.  Caramel colored, tan head.  Body warming sips.  Fruity, spicy flavor.  Smooth beyond belief.
Spicy banana, clove aroma. Flavors of banana(alot of banana), wheat, spices. Abv is well concealed. A nice well rounded weizen

UPDATED: OCT 14, 2009 Pours an amber with a very quickly dissipating 1cm light yellow head.  Aroma is rather malty without much going on.  Start is smoky with a yeast flavor--typically of a belgian.  A very unique and strange brew by the Victory people.  Not a favorite of mine from them.(6/4/7/4/13 9/29/03)----Re-Rate-& ounce bottle purchased from Village Beer Merchant in Buffalo, NY.  Spicy, peppery aroma with plenty of banana yeast esters.  Clove also makes a strong presence.  A little vinousness is also in there.  Moderately hazy amber body with a small quickly dissipating off-pinkish head.  Starts a little sweet, but becomes a bit astringent in the middle.  Lots of banana yeast esters follow.  Some dry, dusty wheat character also makes an appearance.  Seems kind of thin and watery to finish.  It just appears to be lacking.

Burnt hazy orange-brown body with a large taupe head that had a nice waterfall as I poured.  Aromatic banana creme combines with alcohol, cloves and candy sugar for an intoxicating aroma. . . interesting mixture of flavours with good fruits: melons, bananas and strawberries. . .as well as dough, autumn spices (pumpkin) and wheat.  Strength of this brew is in the fruit, and yeast, complex, yet very drinkable.

A really cool hazy blood orange color, similar to a sunset.  The head, while a light tan color, was very small and left no lacing.  An odd, but pleasant, aroma, to be sure.  Very estery with banana, bubblegum, clove, cantelope, alcohol and very slight citrus notes.  Smooth, flavorful body that is neither too thick nor too thin.  The flavor profile very much followed the nose and pleasantly maintained expectations.  Warming, as the alcohol is fairly obvious.  This is one very tasty Weizen Bock.  It has obvious variations from Aventinus, but it's one quality, tasty beer.

Wonderful dark ruby brown haze with big of white head and great lace. Powerful yeast aroma, caramel, fruit. Gigantic beer, full on yeast, candy sugar like a Belgian strong, full wheat body, carbonation is perfectly soft, seems best about 45-50F. Some alcohol in the finish, plus some sharp cheddar, sweet and berries. Incredibly easay to drink yet potent, thoroughly complex. Another victory for Victory.

A pretty solid weizenbock, I must say - dark brown, no real head or lacing, though - spicy, tart aroma, with a hint of pumpkin - flavor is a bit tart as well, but with enough sweetness to balance it out - caramel, banana, cloves and spices mix together to make this a pretty good autumn beer.

Pours with a deep amber-brown body with a slight cloudiness topped by a medium thick off white head with good lacong.  Slightly sweet and yeasty wheaty malt aroma with notes of banana and clove.  Slighlty sweet wheat and malt flavor with slight yeasty notes and subtle notes of banana and other fruits.  The finish is sweet and fruity.  Medium bodied with a tingle from the carbonation.
Average sized fizzy off-white head. Hazy dark orange/amber. Aroma is sweet malty and wheat. Very rich malt and wheat flavors. Hint of alcohol. Creamy medium body. An excellent brew.

Banana beer!  Smells like bananas and tastes like bananas.  Masks the 8.7% ABV very well, and there are no messy banana peels to mess with or slip on.  Elvis would have liked this beer with his grilled peanut butter sandwiches.  Overall it was a good beer, that can get you in trouble if you're not careful, due to the high ABV.

UPDATED: OCT 7, 2003 This beer rocks!
Murky, burnt orange brew. Medium-sized, frothy, lightly tanned head. Retains very well.
Yeasty and spicy nose with lots of clove, banana, and apricot. Some black pepper and bubblegum too.
The flavor is lightly tart and fruity. Nice malt presence. Also, some white wine and white raisin. Well-balanced by the tangy yeast and bitter hops.
Medium-bodied with an oily mouthfeel and fizzy carbonation. Short, crisp, clean finish. I don't care much for wheat beers, but this one is a real winner!

Christmas comes early to Canton NY, formerly a beer wasteland as local beerstore has picked up full Victory line among other notable NY, PA and NE micros!
Wow, first of this style I think I have ever had.  Looks like fresh pressed apple cider, banana and pear nectar, alcohol well hidden.  My guess is that the yeast is same as used in golden monkey.

Dark amber,red color,small head,nice aroma sweet,and spicey with some definate fruit tones to it.The taste was fantastic fruity and spicey with some definate maltiness to it.The after taste was spicey and mildly fruity.This is a wonderful brew and i would highly recommend this one.It has a little of everything and the alcohol really is well hidden IMO I wouldn't drink this one in large amounts but it definately is worth sampling in a limited basis.

UPDATED: OCT 30, 2003 Enjoy by Sep 11 04: Cloudy copper color with a thick dark tan head and a citrusy spiced wheat aroma.  Body is sweet, caramely malty and has a lightly sour sticky warming finish.  Earthy character has some fruity notes as well.  Had a bad/soured bottle previously with expiration date of 3/6/03, but this bottle is much better.  A very nice weizenbock.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2009 2009:  The more I drink this over the years, the less I like it.  Unreastrained spiciness.  Too hot.

2003 batch:  Gee, this is horrible and it has gotten worse as time has gone on.  Bad batch, I should think.  Poured most of it out last night.  My apologies to those I sent it to.  Wont touch ratings until I sample another batch of the 2003 release.

2002 batch:Weizenbocks are wonderful and of course this wonderful brewery produces a wonderful version.  Huge spice, huge tropical fruit in the nose and mouth.  Creamy, wonderful palate.  A first-rate Weizenbock (though I rarely have bad ones).  The only weakness is the strength of the head on this one.  Still, top drawer.

SPices galor in the nose, banana, nutmeg, clove, vanilla, orange zest, touches of doughy yeast, fermenting fruit, alcohol, bandaid, and wheat.  Burning sunset color with globs of yeast floating about but the tan head was too short lived, infact the apearance scor is shearly supported by the color.  As it warms more of a bready malt comes out and helps to balance the dry zesty mouth feel.  Almost like a saison in the mouth.  Loots of citrus in the taste with cloves, minerals, banana bread, and dried fruits.  Banana cloves, wheat in the finish were expected but was also pleasantly surprized by Mint and mellon hideing there too.

1/3/03. A clear ruby amber with a moderate head that fades, leaving some lacing. Banana ester aroma with faint yeastiness. Wonderful sweet, malty flavor with some banana notes and a spicy aftertaste. Rich mouthfeel and warmth from alcohol (not obtrusive). Very enjoyable.

Dark orange gold color. Small head. Aroma is spicy. A full-bodied Weizenbock. Fruity and spicy. Very nice flavors, bananas and cloves, orange and spice, citrus and malts. Well balanced, not only between malts and hops, but between tart and sweet. Very nice beer. No noticeable alcohol despite a 8.7% abv. Mouthfeel is full and round. Finish is clean and smooth. Aftertaste is slightly tart.

Mmmmmmmm.  Dark ochre brown with a cream colored head.  Opaque, with small chunks of suspended yeast.  Smells slightly citric and sweet, with a bit of clove.  Taste is initially sweet and fruity, and sours out pleasantly in the finish.  Great effervescent mouthfeel.

Pours a dark brown with a reddish haze. Strong head that recedes quickly. LOTS of sediment in the bottle. Turns the beer hazy brown. This is a very good thing. Smell citrus fruits and spice with a slight floral hoppiness to it. Does have a sourness to the inital taste but it disappears. Definite fruitness in this. Lemon and orange are dominant. Definitely unique. Recommended though.

Murky amber tones mingle with a quickly disappearing head. Smells like a handful of cloves and a silo full of wheat. There is something about the total blend of flavor in this that makes it really nice I think. There is an initial sour citrus followed by a big wheaty malt, ending with a final flourish of hops that finishes with a peppery spice aftertaste. Very complex and very nice. [2002 batch]
Hazy golden color.  Quickly diminishing head. Quite a bit of carbonation.  Cidery sweet aroma.  Tart, acidic banana taste.
Nice golden orange color.  A big malty and sweet aroma.  BIG clove character, nice malty profile as well.  Spicy, banana, fruit, and a big estery palate to finish.  Really enjoyable beer.

Sweet aroma with a little pepper.  No head at all.  Tastes flat.  Can taste clove, spice, peach.  Has a nice sweet start with a tart hoppy finish.  Has Belgian flavors with German spice.  Gets better and better with every sip.  My overall impression was a 14 at first and is now a 16.

Estery, medium sour, just off dry.  Yeast, fruit hues in a primarily carmel nose, the taste is a solid blend of viney hop, fruit, wheaty grist, and orange/apple.  Its missing a bright spot, but this beer is a champ. Thanks, VENOM!
Wow!  This is one great beer!  The mouthfeel is incredible, the flavor with cloves, citrus and a wonderful fruity finish.  I love this beer!

A wonderfully flavored beer that you can drink all day long.  When German style beers are made as well as this, it is hard to drink anything else.  In a great lineup of beers, this may be Victorys best.

Nice amber weizenbock that possessed a distinctive fruitness that one often finds in Belgians.  Excellent taste and lovely finish.  Strong yeast and grain flavors.  NOTE- Pour slowly as, at least in my bottle, there were bits of the magic yeast extract in the bottom.

UPDATED: SEP 12, 2004 glistining amber atmospheric clouds of froth..aroma was deep maple syrup-like super malty thick and sweet craziness..alcohol firmness in the background..flavor was first slightly acidic turning cereal like in the finish but in the middle it had notes of grapes with added grape tartness that took it out of the weizenbock arena and threw it into the god-knows-what arena..interesting concotion..with a definite banana aftertaste

Medium/dark clear amber - very pretty in the glass. There is a lot going on in the flavor dept and it is bold, but does not assault. The fruit/spice essence is so well balanced that the outcome is just plain delicous. Quite an accomplishment.

Very nice effort from Victory Brewing.
Wonderfully balanced wheat bock.  Nice 
malt flavor to balance the wheat.  Cloves are present as 
well.  Maybe just a little over sweet, but still very good.
Yeasty, fruity, spicy nose.  Feels great in the mouth.  Tart.  Good work.

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2003 Some real variation between bottles.  This bottle had almost no head.  If this is not Aventinus's brother, it certainly is a first cousin.  Color is lighter and redder than Aventinus, and it is a bit less cloudy.  Taste is banana and even a hint of melon, with a strong clove finish.  Spritzy but full mouthfeel.  Sweeter, more sour, and spicier than an Aventinus.  Another great brew from Victory.  // Rerated 8 February.  Incredible variation in the way different bottles age.  Some are still great, like my first bottle, which I loved.  Some are drain pour.  Some are in between.  I left my individual rankings unchanged from my first, perfect bottle.  But accuracy demands that the overall impression ranking reflects the high variation among bottles.  // Rerated the 2003 vintage after having it draft at the brewery.  Cloudy reddish brown with a huge soft foamy tan head.  Mouth filling, huge viscous feel.  Dark malt, sweet fruit, especially melon on top of the more usual banana, with some spice and hoppy bite.  The relationship to Aventinus is even more clear this year.
Orange/copper pour with a thick cream colored head.Tangy wheat nose. Tart and acidic front giving way to fruit and spice.
WOW, great wheat. The 8.7 ABV is tastless. Its very fruity, and ohh so tasty

This beer was a pleasant surprise. Victory is very hard to get in my area, so when I noticed this seasonal I picked up a couple of bottles. What a nice flavor. Beautiful slightly cloudy amber color, w/ a hint of sweetness on the palate. Excellent beer!

Dense cloudy amber body, moderate head formation and light carbonation. Aroma is sweet and spicy, fruity with clove yeast. Fairly full in body, smooth almost syrupy. Sweet candy-like fruitiness, heavy yeast. clove-like with banana flavors coming out late. A little bitterness in the finish but remains sweet and almost sticky in the aftertaste. Ive been drinking the hops for a while now so this was something of a heavy sweet change. Probably a little too sweet for my regular enjoyment but unique and worth the 6-pack. I had no idea it was 8.7% until Id almost finished. Shouldnt it be a Doppelweizenbock?

UPDATED: OCT 5, 2006 (Best by 3/6/03) Strong yeasty nose that is abundant with ripe bananas. Beautiful hazy red color. The head is thin and off-white. The palate is rich and expressive with big flavors, most notable the typical clove and banana associated with this style. This beer is malty, but it is not overly sweet. The alcohol (8.7%) is so well hidden it is almost undetectable. The finish goes on forever, lots of candied fruit flavors with a touch of hop spiciness. It is a very enjoyable beer to have on a cold Baltimore night. A must try for Weizenbock fans.

Sort of a dark, spicy weizenbock with plenty of alcohol (but at 8.7% abv, its well-hidden).  This is clearly a quality brew and I respect Victory for taking a stab at brewing such a challenging and unusual style.  This tasted a lot like Aventinus.

little bananna in the nose, got some good malt, grainy aromas also. slightly phenolic.head is gone real quick.taste some alc in the background.hazy brown color.Got some nice chunks floatin around.Decent brew. Still dig their friggin hop monsters more though!

Hazy dark amber body with minimal head.  Aroma is spicy (mostly clove) and malty, slightly fruity (pear?) too.  Taste is rich, mostly sweet wheat, but also malty, tart/acidic, and ever-so-slightly banana and pear.  Slightly sticky mouthfeel.  And oh yeah, its got HOW MUCH alcohol?  Damn -- youd never know.

hazy amber.
has a hefeweizen clove banana aroma. the taste is malty and smooth with  wheat beer fruit overtones hasa oktoberfest/hefeweizen blend quality  to it alcohol presence makes it self apparent in the  dry finish and astringent aftertaste

UPDATED: JUN 12, 2003 Rating #1 - Bottle (9 4 8 4 16).  A cloudy brown with a touch of red and a healthy looking light brown head.  A tart and malty aroma.  The flavor is vinous, citric, malty, and slightly sour.  This one is less weizen than other weizen bock beers I have had.  It takes some of the spice and fruit qualities of the weizen, but the main thrust of the beer is the malty bock.  Rating #2 - Bottle (8, 4, 7, 4, 16).  A murky swamp brownish color with a laced tan head.  The aroma has a spice that is a little sweet before it gives way to a malty bock nose.  A citrus tart bite hits the flavor palate and melds into a german wheat and malty bock body while maintaining the dry tartness throughout.

Never had a weizenbock before this one, but i really liked it.  Good head, but if you pour in the yeasties, it clouds up the color which is deep orange/amber.  I think the added yeast helped in the aroma, which was of pear, and clover, and other fruitiness.  Started out tasting more fruity, and finished up slightly spicy.  Really smooth- alcohol is hidden really well, although it left a slight zing on my lips after it went down.  Not too carbonated, which made it go down nice and easy.  Well worth the price for a whole case.  It will be gone fast.
almost like a hefeweizen, slight caramel with the clove/banana, alcohol hid well
This to me tasted a slight bit cider-y.  You could taste the alcohol and what tasted like pears.  Orange-amber appearance, decent head.  Excellent Brew.
Hazy burnt orange, fizzy.  Smelled and tasted of alcohol and spicy pears along with a sweet yeasty finish.  Very easy to drink, very tastey.

5 on appearance just because Victorys labels are so freakin cool.  As for the beer, it was amber and slightly cloudy, average head.  Caramel, pears, hints of cideriness in the aroma and flavor.  The strong wheatiness is overcome by silghtly stronger hoppiness in an interesting way.  The alcohol content was well utilized: not prominent at all, but you could detect it adding complexity if you looked for it.  Excellent dry finish, another winner from Victory.
Ya have tro give the Victory boys a hand for trying but this isnt what its suppost to be

Lovely red amber color with a perfect cream head.  This beeer gives off a grainy malt odor of an unrefined nature.  The sweet malt flavor is subjugated after the creamy from gives way to the desert wine taste--that leaves touches of cough syrup on the tongues tip. The body betters as the beer airs and warms--becoming more mature and developed.  The alcohol is masked well, blending to accentuate the beers piquant notes.

There is no longer any doubt in my mind that Victory is the best brewery in the states.  Wow.  Aubrey, I should have just had you send me six of these!  Beautifully redgold muddy and alive in the glass with a pungent inhale that trumpets WHEAT.  I just plain out love the contrast between the mouth puckering citrus and the smooth, creamy, banana action.  Actually, now that I think about it, its a good thing I dont have six of these, because Id be a hopeless wreck for the dinner party Im supposed to be hosting tonight.  This is a great beer!

You know youll get a flavorful brew when you see the Victory name, but this is one of the least impressive Ive had of their line.  Deep, cloudy auburn color with a medium off-white head.  Carbonation just kept going and going, and bubbles were still rising 3/4 of the way through the beer.  Yeasty, caramelly and slightly sour aromas with bready malts and yeast in the flavor profile.  The finish is quite sour - sour apple - with hop bitterness complimenting.  Flavor is fairly full and the brew sits well on the tongue.  A good beer, but not outstanding like many other Victory brews.

UPDATED: JUN 28, 2005 Soviet Red with a big-bubbled and lasting head. A little cloudy, with some juicy floaties swimming about. Estery nose. Big sour-citric flavor. A little yeasty... and a little spicy. Reminds me of Rodenbach Grand Cru a little. Very citrusy and sour, mouth-puckering finish was great. Loved it! Rerate: Hazy and deep red-orange with a frothy head. Yeasty nose. Nice and rich texture; sort of milkshake-like. Malts were wheaty and doughy, and rather sugary. Flowery, balancing bitterness. Complex fruit notes throughout, such as plums, apricots, prunes and raisins.
mmmm good... crisp and dry yet malty.... strong but very easy to drink... enjoying a glass right now.  easily my favorite wheat beer as of recent...
SOme great flavors intermixed with some unwelcome ones.  Heavy esters.  Almost underattenuated.  A tough style.

UPDATED: JAN 1, 2008 Aroma is dominated by fruity notes of apples, musty yeast and hint of caramel malt.  Palate is much lighter than I expected.  Pours with a cloudy orange-brown color with fast dissipating head that ends up in a whisp of bubbles.  Unexpected sour taste (green apples) with undertones of numbing caramel. Not bad.
user_location: Blue Ridge Mountains, North Carolina, USA

text: A dangerous beer that in no way hints that it is almost 9%.  I got a spoiled apple taste that I couldnt get to like.  Thanks VENOM!

Im a little disappointed with this one.  All I got was apples, sour apples and lots of them.  Maybe I am basing all my expectations on the aventinus standard, but I expected much more of the clove/banana phenolic flavor.  I actually held back on rating this beer after my first taste to see if I got the same flavor out of more than one bottle, sadly I did.  I will try this beer again, I hope it fares better.  One good thing I can say is that it hid its alcohol well.

Unfiltered, deep copper. Looks like apple cider. Smells of cloves, apples and other spices.  Malt,banana, cloves, pears and  a citric pop on the palate that is melded together quite impressivley. The citric acidity adds some balance and character. Could use a little more body but im not complaining.  Wait, theres alcohol in this? Superb brewing. Nicely done and quite the treat.  If comparing to Aventinus, not as thick or creamy but stands on its own quite well. Definitley top shelf and is  something to come back to. Thank you Venom!!
An outstanding interpretation of a wheat bock.  Theos pupils have learned well.
This stuff is excellent.  Typical wheat beer profile highliting the banana and clove undertones in the taste and aroma.  Silky smooth mouthfeel, and dangerously drinkable.

Cloudy, dirty brown; Head starts thick and dissipates quickly; Lots of apples in the aroma.
This one completely reminded me of old-style apple juice in appearance and aroma. Alcohol masked completely until about 3/4 through when you feel it in your head. The palate was maybe the most disappointing aspect of this beer, I really expect more heft in the mouth when I drink this style. Every other weizen-bock that I ever had was full of bananas and I thought it was strange that this one was all apples. I saw pears in other reviews, but I sensed apples. I will definitely need to revisit this one. Thank you VENOM!!

VENOM is giving this one away like it was Big Daddy IPA, but I dont see anyone complaining.  Its been a while I had the opportunity to catapult a beer into the Top Ten, but Im afraid it wont happen today.  Very nice beer, though - cloudy chestnut appearance; lovely aroma of banana, soft malt (biscuits, soft caramel tones) and pears.  The palate is a little less complex, but brings wheat, pears and rounded malt flavours to the table.  It is fairly acidic, and that helps balance out the malts, leaving the brew far more drinkable than one would prefer an 8.7%er to be.
Awesome. Fruity and yeasty aroma, dark cloudy light brown color. Fruity, apple and citrus tastes with a distinct malty finish. A new beer for my top ten.
This is real nice.  Love the yeast notes in this one.  Fruit/citrus highlights in the middle, finishes with a great malt character. This is delicious.

UPDATED: OCT 21, 2004 Wooooo.  Nose wheaty, whiffs of bubblegum and yeast, slightly earthy as well, quite intriguing.  Initial flavor is sharp and zesty, very fruity, lemony, and crisp.  The finish is wonderfully smooth and malty, nice sweetness with some hints of caramel and qutie bready.  An incredibly interesting brew.  Sits absolutely beautifully, lovely cloudy texture.
Great nose, large head and generous lace. Malt start, a bit tart and a nice cloudy dark amber color. Hops are present as is the high abv in the after taste. Damn good beer. thanks Venom.
Whoa! Hold on! When a beer is compared favorably to Aventinus that is made by an American brewer, its worth trying! Rich, Spicy,yeasty what a fantastic beer!
Very much like Aventinus, but alittle spicier and slightly lemony. Malty and sharp on the tongue. Very tasty.

Note quite delectable, this delicious beer exhibits a malty banana, slightly spicy aroma.  Unfiltered dark brown without much head. Sharp taste, primarily banana and malt accompany the underlying warming alcohol.  Aventinus is a touch smoother, however the smooth plum, banana, and fudge finish is noteworthy and quite memorable.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2003 This is now called the Moonglow Weizenbock, and what a great beer it is. It contains all the best traits of both a bock and a weizen. Aroma is full of the yeasty/spicy notes of banana, clove and lemon zest - yet also sweetly malty. Flavor is more of the same, without the lemon zest. Medium bodied, giving it the kick of a bock and the refreshing quaffability of a weizen. Very nice.

Update: less of the weizeny esters are present and this beer is dominated by a sweet melanoidin palate and a strong alcoholic finish. A notable acidity, I think, plays a role in diminishing the esters. Enjoyed the cloudy blood-orange glow in the glass, though - a nice treat on Halloween night.
excellent, strong beer
